CHAPTER XV. CONCERNING THE SACRAMENTS

I. Of the Sacraments in General

A. Etymology and Various Significations of the Term “Sacrament”

I. Sacraments, so called—the word being transferred from military affairs to sacred matters—are considered either in general or in specific cases.

GOM. The word “sacrament” is derived not from secret powers, as Isidore wrongly conjectures in Originum lib. c. 19, but from sacrum [sacred], as Varro says in De lingua Latina l. 4. Among other meanings, approved Latin authorities use it to denote the military oath of soldiers, as in Cicero De off. 1.1 and Suetonius Julius Caesar, cap. 42 (whence the ancient Glossary notes: Sacrament, opē stratiōtikos [Greek: soldier’s oath]), by which, through certain rites, they were consecrated to render fidelity and obedience to their commander. For (as Vegetius says in De re militari 1.2 c.5) soldiers are marked with punctures on the skin, namely of the hand—whence in the law of Mauritius “signed in the hand” is a circumlocution for soldiers, as in Gregory the Great l.3 ep.100—when they are enrolled in the military registers, they are accustomed to swear; and therefore they are called military sacraments, etc. Soldiers swear that they will do all things strenuously which the Emperor commands, that they will never desert their military service, nor refuse death for the Roman republic. Hence, from military affairs to sacred matters, the metaphor has been elegantly transferred. For, as not only a Christian writer, Augustine Tom. 10 De tempore Serm. 181, expressly testifies, but even a pagan philosopher acknowledged: theō edei kē hēmas homonphyn, hoion hoi stratiotai, tō kaisari [Greek: it behooves us to swear to God, as soldiers to Caesar]—so it befits us also to swear to God, as soldiers to Caesar. And therefore, the word “sacrament” was transferred by the more ancient Fathers to the signs of God’s covenant through Christ (by which we are consecrated to God as our heavenly Emperor for sacred warfare), although they would have named them more clearly, fully, and safely as “signs of the covenant,” Gen. 17:11, with God as our guide. Tertullian, however, was the first to call baptism and the Eucharist “sacraments,” whom Cyprian afterward followed in Serm. de Cana., Ambrose in lib. de sacram., Jerome, and Augustine, from whom this name spread more widely to others and has been received by the common usage of the Church until now. Yet its usage is diverse. For it is taken either relatively, for a sign, as Augustine in In Joh. Tract. 26, 27, or absolutely for both, both sign and thing signified. As when they say a sacrament consists of an earthly and a heavenly thing—which Irenaeus says about the Eucharist, l.4 c.34. Of these significations, the former is proper and genuine to the nature of sacraments (as is evident from the kind and induction of each). From this also arose that opposition in the writings of the Fathers between “sacrament” and “thing,” “truth,” “grace,” “power of the sacrament,” “figure,” and “truth.”

WAL. The Greeks call them mysteria [mysteries] from myō [to close], whence also mysēs [initiate], which properly signifies to hide, because under external appearances something else is hidden, not indeed in the thing itself, but in signification and use: as in Scripture Apoc. 1:20, the mystery, or sacrament, of the seven stars is said to be the seven churches; and Apoc. 17:5, the harlot seated on the beast is called the mystery or sacrament of Babylon and of the beast that carries her. 1 Tim. 3:16: “Great is the mystery [sacrament] of godliness.” Thus this word is also translated Eph. 5:32 and 1:9 and 3:3, Col. 1:26, etc. This word is not used in Scripture for our sacraments: for that passage Eph. 5:31 is not taken concerning external marriage, but concerning the mystical union of Christ and the Church. Holy Scripture properly calls them othot [Hebrew: signs], or signs of the covenant, and signs between God and the people, as Gen. 17:10: “This is the sign of the covenant between me and you.” Concerning the Paschal lamb, Ex. 12:13: “That it may be a sign between me and you.” Thus concerning the Sabbath, Ex. 31:13: “The children of Israel shall observe the Sabbath, because it is a sign between me and the children of Israel forever.” Thus Ezek. 20:12: “I gave them my sabbaths, that they might be a sign between me and you, that I the LORD do sanctify you.” Paul preserved this signification Rom. 4:11, where he calls circumcision a sign which Abraham received. Therefore those contend absurdly that sacraments should not be defined by the word “sign,” when Scripture uses it so clearly. Would that the Church had been content with this word!

TRELC. A twofold account of these is customarily and ought to be given and explained: one general concerning all; the other special, concerning individual sacraments. By the name “sacrament” (which has been transferred from military matters to Christian rites) we do not understand, in the broadest signification through metalepsis, every mystery, secret, and arcanum of a sacred or divine thing; by which signification the Gospel, the Incarnation of Christ, the calling of the Gentiles, etc. are accustomed to be indicated in the Scriptures. Nor in a less general signification, through catachresis, do we understand every symbolic divine mystery and arcanum, or everything which, beyond the appearance presented to the senses, signifies something else; such as ceremonies, types, parables, signs, and figures are, all of which, because they pertain to divine things, were called sacraments by the ancients: but in the stricter and especially proper signification, by the name “sacrament” we understand a sign of grace, instituted by God, both to seal His benefits in us and to consecrate us to Himself forever. For in the signification of a sacrament there is a mutual respect: one from God’s side, offering grace; the other from man’s side, promising gratitude. And in this sense the word “sacrament” is customarily used in two ways: either synecdochically for the sign alone and the thing signified, or properly for both, or for that entire sacred action which concurs for the just participation of a sacrament.

B. Essential Definition of a Sacrament

II. A sacrament is a sacred sign and seal of God’s grace in Christ.

CALV. In the first place, it is fitting to observe what a sacrament is. It seems to me that this will be a simple and proper definition if we say that it is an external symbol by which the Lord seals on our consciences the promises of His good will toward us, to sustain the weakness of our faith; and we in turn testify our piety toward Him both before Him and the angels, and before men. It is also permitted to define it otherwise with greater brevity: that it may be called a testimony of God’s grace toward us, confirmed by an external sign, with a mutual attestation of our piety toward Him. Whichever of these definitions you choose, it differs in sense not at all from that of Augustine, who says that a sacrament is a visible sign of a sacred thing, or the visible form of invisible grace: but it explains the thing itself better and more certainly. For since in that brevity there is some obscurity in which many of the more unlearned err, I wished to render the meaning fuller with more words, lest any doubt should remain.

C. The Efficient Cause: God as the Sole Institutor

III. Their efficient cause and institutor is God.

JUN. We establish as the efficient cause God alone, and Christ the Mediator, because it belongs only to them to institute a sign who have the right to promise the thing signified and the power to apply it. But no man knows the counsels of God, Rom. 11:34, Isa. 41:18, nor can anyone promise evangelical grace and remission of sins from himself, or actually remit sins, except God alone, Isa. 43:25. Wherefore not only do signs ordained by human will deceive us, but they also inflict the greatest injury upon God, who take upon themselves so much authority without His word.

D. The Material Cause: Sign and Thing Signified

IV. They consist, as matter, of sign and thing signified.

JUN. The matter is bipartite: external and internal. The external is whatever is subject to the senses, whether it be symbol, action, or word. The symbol is that element which is communicated by the hand of the minister to the recipient: such as water in baptism, and bread and wine in the Supper; which alone is customarily called matter by many. The action is that ceremony of the minister and the faithful in the participation of the sacrament, which, insofar as it is external, takes on the character of matter. The word, however, is twofold: of institution and of promise. To the first belong these: “Go, teach, baptizing,” etc., Matt. 28:19, Mark 16:15; and, “He took bread,” etc., Matt. 26:26. To the second belong these: “In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit”; and in the Supper, “This is my body,” which we consider as matter only insofar as it is perceived by hearing and is rendered sensible. The internal matter is chiefly Christ Himself, Gal. 3:27, Rom. 6:3, to whom we must be engrafted by faith: then His benefits, John 15:4, which, like vital juices, are diffused from the root into all His branches, and thus at length form and produce in us the fruits of good works.

GOM. For if the word of command be absent, it will not be a divinely instituted sign; if the word of promise is absent, it will not be a seal of the covenant, and therefore not a sacrament at all. In which sense also, by Ambrose, De Sacram. l.4 c.4, it is said: “The word is operative, that what were become, and are changed into another thing.” Therefore a certain change and conversion exists in the sacraments: not indeed of the essence of the signs into the thing signified through metousiōsis [Greek: transubstantiation] (otherwise they would cease to be signs and sacraments), nor of implanted properties through the infusion of a new quality, because the Holy Scriptures do not teach this; but the change is only of natural use, through God’s gratuitous institution, by which an absolute thing becomes relative and is consecrated and converted into a sign of the covenant and a sacrament. Thus Theodoret rightly acknowledges tēn ek tēs charitos metabolēn [Greek: the change which is from grace], Dial. 1, but utterly denies tēs physeōs metabolēn [Greek: change of nature]. But what seems to be stated to the contrary by some of the Fathers should be understood not concerning the essence of nature but concerning its use. Namely, that the natural use of the elements (as they call it) is changed by the word into a supernatural, mystical, and heavenly use, and is designated by the name of the thing signified.

E. The Formal Cause: The Analogy and Relation Between Sign and Signified

V. The form consists in the agreement and analogy of the signs with the thing signified.

TRELC. The internal and proper form of a sacrament is indeed that most beautiful analogia [Greek: analogy] of the sign to the thing signified, and the mutual relation of one to the other, of which the former properly consists in the comparison and similitude of properties, the latter in the ordination of the sign to the thing signified. This conjunction of signs and things signified in the sacraments is not natural, through substantial contact and connection, or union of accidents and substances; not local, through non-distance or inexistence of one in the other; nor even spiritual, immediately vivifying the signs themselves; but wholly relative and sacramental, consisting chiefly in three things: in signification, in sealing, and in exhibition of the thing signified. In signification, because the signs, by most fitting similitude and analogia [analogy], as if by a certain introduction, represent spiritual mysteries, that is, invisible things through visible things, Gen. 17:10-11, 1 Cor. 11:14, 16, John 6:13, 1 John 1:7. And this bond of similitude is properly so called; which if sacraments did not have, they would not even be sacraments. In sealing, because the signs are and are called seals or sphragides [Greek: seals] of the things signified; both because they confirm the truth of the similitude between sign and thing signified, and also because they seal most certainly and necessarily the efficacy of the conjunction of both in legitimate use. And this bond of sealing is so called. In exhibition, because that which is figured by the signs is truly exhibited. For God does not mock in instituting signs of which there is no truth: but as in the vocal word, so also in the sign, that is, the visible word, He truly furnishes what He promises and shows. Yet the exhibition or perception of the thing signified is not referred to the organs of the body but to the mind of the believer, because it is spiritual, just as the exhibition and perception of the signs is corporeal. We call it spiritual for a twofold reason: both by its efficient cause, that is, by the secret operation of the Holy Spirit, by which it happens in a truly wonderful manner that through the intervention of Christ’s flesh mystically communicated to us, the power of Christ’s blood and merit penetrates even to our souls; and by its instrument, because faith, by which we perceive it, is a spiritual instrument, by whose bond the Spirit most closely joins things which otherwise are most widely separated.

GOM. The form and systaltikē [Greek: constitutive] difference of a sacrament (because it is a relative thing) consists in the relation of this sign to its signified terminus, or thing signified: that is, in its ordination to the visible signification and sealing of that grace of the covenant. For this both constitutes the essence of the sacrament and makes it differ from all things. Since this relation intervenes like a bond between the sign and the thing signified, and as it were joins and somehow unites two termini, therefore by a new and obscure phrase, in imitation of the Ubiquitarians, it is commonly called, not quite correctly, “sacramental union.” Because the thing signified is more truly united to us, John 6:56, 1 Cor. 12:13, Gal. 2:20, Eph. 5:30, than to the signs, and this is denoted and confirmed by the signs. Wherefore this union is not ousiōdēs [Greek: substantial] and absolute, but schetikē [Greek: relative]. Because it is not occupied in the concealment of the thing under the sign, nor in the same mode of perception of thing and sign, but partly in the similitude of sign and thing signified, partly in the certainty of the communication of the sealed thing in the legitimate use of the sign, according to God’s covenant. For the sign and the signified grace of God’s covenant are perceived simultaneously by believers, Gen. 17:7, 11, Ex. 12:13, Ps. 51:9, Mark 16:16, Gal. 3:27—but not similarly. Simultaneously indeed, not simply and absolutely, but only insofar as it is declared by the word. Because the sealed grace is partly past, partly present, partly future, according to the substance and circumstance of the covenant and pact. Just as in Abraham’s circumcision, the past grace was the preceding righteousness of faith, Gen. 15:6 and Rom. 4:11; the present, that God was his God and the continuation of his righteousness; the future, that God would continue to be his God, Gen. 17:7, and therefore would preserve him, Matt. 22:32, and bestow heaven upon him (shadowed forth in the promise of Canaan), Gen. 17:8, Heb. 11:9; finally, that He would produce Christ from his seed, in whom he would become the father of many nations, Gen. 14:4 and 22:18. But not similarly, nor by the same instrument, are signs and things signified exhibited and perceived: but (according to their diverse condition) the signs, offered by the minister, are perceived by the bodily senses; but the things signified, conferred by the Lord, are received by believers in heart and with true faith. In which the legitimate, or worthy and salutary, use of receiving the sacrament by us is contained. And in this mind certain ancient theologians affirmed that in visible seals, and under a visible appearance, an invisible thing is perceived. As also Irenaeus l.4 c.34, not absolutely with respect to all communicants, but relatively to believers and those to be saved, says the Eucharist consists of two things, earthly and heavenly: not as integral parts situated in the same place, but because they are simultaneously offered and accepted, though in a different manner. And therefore he establishes that the salutary resurrection is the fruit of this Eucharist, which belongs to believers alone around the controversy. From which also it is sufficiently clear that they err grievously, first, who contend that sacraments are bare signs, destitute of exhibition and perception of the thing, and only tokens of external profession; then, who impudently feign that such things are established by us.

F. Sacramental Predication: Metonymy in Sacramental Language

VI. And hence arose in discourse the metonymical sacramental predication.

GOM. And thus concerning the form and constitutive difference of a sacrament. Of this form and relation, not only the effect but also, for our consolation, the indication is sacramental predication, which Theodoret, Dial. 1, rightly calls synallōysis onomatōn [Greek: exchange of names]. He says its cause is that those using the sacraments might not be intent upon the nature of the things which are seen, but through the exchange of names might believe in that change which has been made by grace. Sacramental predication is so called by which the names and attributes of the sacrament and the thing (or sign and thing signified) are interchanged among themselves, through metonymy, customary in discourse concerning signs of all kinds, but especially sacramental ones, in both testaments, as examples demonstrate. For in the Old Testament, when signs are treated, the seven cows and also ears are seven years, Gen. 41:26; the tree is the king, Dan. 4:17, 19; the four beasts are four kingdoms, ibid. 7:17; the ten horns are ten kings, ibid. 16, 24. In the New Testament also, the field is the world, Matt. 12:38-39; the good seed are the sons of the kingdom; and the harvest is the consummation of the age; the reapers are the angels; the seven heads are seven mountains; the ten horns are ten kings, Apoc. 17:9, 12—that is, their signs. See Augustine l.4 Qu. in Lev. 57. In the sacraments there is a similar principle. For in the Old Testament it is said, circumcision is the covenant, Gen. 17:13, because it is the sign of the covenant, ibid. 17:11, as God explains; the lamb is the Passover, Exod. 12:7, 11, 21, that is, the passing over, because it is the sign of it, ibid. 12:13, 27. In the New Testament similarly; the rock was Christ, 1 Cor. 10:4; baptism is the washing away of sins, Acts 22:16, and the laver of regeneration, Tit. 3:5; the bread is the body, 1 Cor. 11:24, and at the same time is the communion of the body of Christ, ibid. 10:16; the cup is the new covenant, Luke 22:20, 1 Cor. 11:25, and the blood is Christ’s, Mark 14:24, and also is the communion of the blood of Christ, 1 Cor. 10:16. All of which are said thus, not by reason of substance but of signification, as Augustine learnedly says, Tom. 4 Qu. in Lev. 57, and as Theodoret says, Dial. 1, not by change of nature but by addition of grace: because they are their signs and sacraments. Wherefore the Ubiquitarians quite ineptly call it an unusual predication, when it is most usual. Concerning which the famous sentence of Augustine, also praised by the Papists (Sent. l.4 dist.1), says: “If sacraments did not have a certain similitude of those things of which they are sacraments, they would not be sacraments at all. But from this similitude, for the most part, they also receive the names of the things themselves. Just as, therefore, according to a certain manner, the sacrament of the body of Christ is the body of Christ, so the sacrament of faith is faith,” Ep. 23 to Boniface. And elsewhere: “The thing which signifies is accustomed to be called by the name of that thing which it signifies,” in Lev. 457. Likewise: “Sometimes the thing which signifies receives the name of the thing which it signifies, etc. For thus also the rock was Christ, because it signified Christ,” Ep. 102 to Evodius. And before Augustine, Tertullian says: “Having taken bread and distributed it, He made it His body, saying, ‘This is my body’: that is, the figure of my body,” contra Marc. l.4 c.45. And Cyprian, speaking of bread and wine, body and blood, says: “That things signifying and things signified are designated by the same names,” Serm. de unctione chrismatis. Finally Ambrose says: “As you have received the similitude of death, so also you drink the similitude of the precious blood,” De Sacram. l.4 c.4. From which the sacramental hyperboles of the ancients can and ought to be understood without any error. Hence Augustine piously says: “As to follow the letter and to take signs for the things which are signified by them is of servile weakness, so to interpret signs unprofitably is of ill-wandering error,” De doctr. Chr. l.3 c.9.

TRELC. From this internal form of a sacrament, and the mutual affection of sign and thing signified, arise two principal kinds of sacramental predications used in the Scriptures. The first, when the sign is predicated of the thing signified, that is, the sign is said to be the thing signified itself: as when circumcision is called the covenant; our Passover, Christ. The second, when the thing signified is predicated of the sign, that is, the thing itself signified is said to be the sign: as when the bread is called the body of Christ, and the wine the blood of Christ. And these predications are customarily called relative, analogical, and metonymical. Relative, because when a disparate thing is predicated of a disparate thing, the relation and mutual disposition of things similar to each other is necessarily presupposed. Analogical, because the exchange of names happens on account of the analogy and the highest agreement among themselves. Metonymical, because the sign is put for the thing signified, and vice versa.

G. The Final Cause: The Primary End of Sealing Grace to the Faithful

VII. The primary end of the sacraments is to seal the grace of Christ to believers.

JUN. The proper end is twofold: primary and secondary. The primary is to signify and designate in the hearts of believers the grace of God the Father in His Son, Rom. 6:4, 1 Cor. 10:16, as a seal seals the promises contained in a charter, Rom. 4:11, and to confer the same through the Spirit to those rightly using the instrument of the word and seal, Matt. 16:25. The secondary is threefold: I. That believers might testify their gratitude toward God by commemoration of Christ and proclamation of His death. II. That they might exercise charity among themselves by the bond of society. III. That by this mark they might be separated from all the synagogues of Satan. The accidental end is condemnation of those communicating unworthily, 1 Cor. 12:19. For God, since He is a just judge, cannot avenge so great a contumely inflicted both upon Himself and upon His Son with less punishment than eternal condemnation. We therefore reject the opinions of those, as noxious and heretical, who, by excessively attenuating the sacrament, select only one of these ends, and teach that sacraments are only signs of grace conferred before and outside the sacrament, or marks of Christians, or only symbols of mutual charity, or certain reminders in the manner of pictures.

CALV. Wherefore let it remain fixed that sacraments have no other parts than those of the Word of God, which are to offer and set forth to us Christ, and in Him the treasures of heavenly grace; but they confer or profit nothing unless accepted by faith, not otherwise than wine or oil or any other liquid, however abundantly poured in, will nevertheless flow out and perish unless the mouth of the vessel is open; but the vessel itself, although thoroughly drenched on every side, will nevertheless remain empty and void.

H. The Number of Sacraments in the New Testament

VIII. The sacraments of the New Testament are two: baptism and the Supper.

TRELC. Some sacraments are of the Old, others of the New Testament. Those of the Old Testament are of two kinds. For some were temporary, accidental, and extraordinary, which God used only once or for a certain time. And of these, some correspond to our baptism, such as the passage through the Red Sea, the flood, the sojourn under the cloud. Others correspond to the Lord’s Supper, such as manna given from heaven and water from the rock. Others were fixed and ordinary, namely, whose use continued until the time of the new covenant, which were especially two: circumcision and Passover—the former a symbol and sacrament of initiation or reception into the covenant, the latter of continuation in the covenant. Which are called special because they were both antitypa [Greek: antitypes] of the New Testament, and because they sealed the promise of grace and its application made to individuals, by which twofold designation they are distinguished from all other sacraments, which in the Old Testament were many. The sacraments of the New Testament are two: one of initiation, baptism, which succeeded circumcision; the other of nourishment or sustenance, the Lord’s Supper.

WAL. That there are only two is proved. I. Because to these alone the true definition of sacraments applies, as is evident from the comparison of the superior definition and the rest. II. From passages of Scripture: for the Apostle Paul himself, 1 Cor. 10, when he compares the character of the sacraments of the ancients and of the new ones which the Corinthians were using more insolently, makes mention only of these two, namely baptism and the Supper. Thus 1 Cor. 12:13: “We were baptized into one body, we were made to drink into one Spirit.” III. Because in the Old Testament there were only two properly so called and ordinary, common to the whole Church: namely circumcision and Passover; before the law, the tree of life and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil. And a fitting reason is given: that just as for the good first constitution of man there is required creation or generation, then continuation and confirmation, so in spiritual matters two sacraments suffice, of which one seals our regeneration or recreation, the other confirmation and strengthening in it.

ZANCH. We confess with Augustine, De doctr. Christiana lib.3 cap.9, that the sacraments handed down to us by Christ are few in number, easy in performance, and most august in understanding: few in number, because only two, baptism and the Supper; easy in performance, because there is nothing either in baptism or in the Supper which cannot be easily performed and received, nothing burdensome, nothing unpleasant, or alien to human customs; finally, most august in understanding, because although the things which are seen are lowly, those things which are signified, or which are proposed to the mind for thinking and considering and understanding, are most august, heavenly, divine, pertaining to eternal salvation.

I. Rejection of the Five Papal Additions

IX. But what the Papists add—Confirmation, Penance, Extreme Unction, Orders, and Matrimony—are not true sacraments.

JUN. We assert therefore that there are only two sacraments in number for the whole Church under the New Testament, which, that they may be true and legitimate, require Christ’s institution as the formative rule prescribed for the whole Church in the communication of grace and the public obligation and application of the entire Gospel to individual members of it. And therefore, since these things are found only in our sacraments, namely baptism and the Eucharist, we reject not undeservedly the septenary number of the Papists, of which the first agrees in substance with ours, and therefore we do not repeat it; the second in name only, and therefore we disapprove; both agree in number, and in that we do not disagree; but the remaining five, as plucked from human imagination, we affirm are thrust upon the Church by injury as sacraments. For first, the whole definition of a sacrament applies to none of them. Then penance does not have a visible sign. For if hearing alone could suffice for greater confirmation of faith, why would not a sermon also be a sacrament? Indeed, it ought rather to be, since what is explained in more words is clearer than when it is said, “I absolve you,” etc. Finally, in confirmation the word of command and of evangelical promise is lacking. In extreme unction, the promise made to us. In ecclesiastical orders, the sign instituted by Christ and the evangelical promise. In matrimony, the word both of promise and of institution. For not every parable and similitude will be called a sacrament of the New Testament—otherwise we would establish not seven, but almost infinite sacraments.

II. Of the Sacrament of Baptism

A. Of the Etymology and Definition of Baptism

X. Baptism is the first sacrament of the New Testament, by which believers are certified of the washing away of their sins through the blood and Spirit of Christ.

GOM. One sacrament is of initiation, Gen. 17:11, Matt. 28:19; another of confirmation, Ex. 12:47, Luke 22:19. Of these, the former is a sign of reception into covenant with God, and therefore is performed only once; but the latter is a symbol of continuation in the covenant begun, and therefore is to be repeated frequently, Ex. 12:14, 1 Cor. 11:25-26. From baptō [Greek: to dip] comes the frequentative baptizō [Greek: to baptize], which Tertullian properly renders mergitare [to dip repeatedly], De corona c.3, and through metonymy of the efficient cause, to dye and to wash, De bapt. c.4—in which sense also it is used in the sacred writings, Mark 7:4. Just as the Hebrew tabhal [to dip], to dip, to dye (which the LXX translates baptō, Lev. 4:6, and baptizō, 2 Kings 5:14) and rachats [to wash], to wash, are used interchangeably in the same sense, 2 Kings 5:13. And thus Sirach expounds baptizomenon apo nekrou [Greek: one who washes after touching a dead body], concerning washing, Ecclus. 34:36. From this word are derived baptismos, Mark 7:4, 8, and baptisma [Greek: baptism], Heb. 6:2. These denote the act of baptizing, that is, either immersion alone or dipping and subsequent washing, Mark 5:4, 8—and in this sense it is called katharismos [Greek: purification], John 3:25. Hence Isidore interprets baptism as, in Greek, tinctio [dyeing] in Latin, Orig. l.6 c.19. Wherefore also by Tertullian it is called intinctio [dipping], De pænit. c.5 and 6, and commonly baptism of the river and of water, John 1:26. And it is the first sacrament of the New Testament, instituted by God and promulgated through John the Baptist and Jesus Christ, by which all who are covenanted to God through Christ ought to be dyed with water by a minister of the Gospel, in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, to signify and seal their reception into the new covenant of grace exhibited through Jesus Christ, and the confirmation of faith and repentance.

MACC. Baptism is a sacrament of the New Testament by which, through sprinkling with water in the name of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, the benefit of purification from sin through the Son of God and regeneration unto eternal life is signified and sealed to believers.

B. The Efficient Cause of Baptism: God, and Christ as the Institutor

XI. The efficient cause is Christ, who instituted baptism as a sacrament for the Church of the New Testament.

GOM. Its author and lawgiver is God, who by His word, both of His command and of grace promised in the Gospel, first instituted it for the Church of the Jews, John 1:6-7, 33, Luke 3:2-3; then confirmed and ratified the institution by Christ’s use of it and by the most illustrious manifestation of the three Persons in the same place, Matt. 3:16; finally propagated it to the Church to be gathered from all nations, by the order of perpetual observance, Matt. 28:19, Mark 16:16. And therefore baptism is said to be from heaven, Matt. 21:25, and the counsel of God, Luke 7:30; indeed, the work of God, Eph. 5:26, Tit. 3:4, whose obedience is righteousness, Matt. 3:15, but disobedience is contempt of God, Luke 7:30. Whence by Lactantius it is rightly called the heavenly washing, Divinar. inst. l.7 c.5.

MACC. The signification of this institution is through the solemn words which are also found in Matt. 28:19.

Our adversaries here oppose us and say that this passage does not treat of water baptism. I. Because the Apostles are not read to have used this formula in baptism, for they are simply said to have baptized in the name of Christ, Acts 2, 8, 10, 19. Secondly, they say, if Christ commanded to baptize in the name of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, then Paul could not have said, 1 Cor. 1:17: “For the Lord did not send me to baptize, but to evangelize.” They conclude finally that baptism in the name of the Father and Son and Holy Spirit is not water baptism, but doctrine. But, to begin from the last point, we say that two different things were imposed upon the disciples in Matt. 28: to teach and to baptize, for it is said there: “He who believes and is baptized shall be saved.” To believe is not the same as to be baptized, but after one has believed, he ought also to be baptized. Wherefore to teach things to be believed will not be the same as to baptize. For they are commanded first to teach, that they may believe; then to be baptized, after they have believed. For thus also to the Eunuch seeking baptism from Philip it was said: “If you believe with all your heart, it is permitted,” Acts 8:37. It follows that nowhere in Scripture is the doctrine of the Gospel called baptism; nor are evangelizing and baptizing anywhere taken as the same, nor were those who believed in Christ, before they were dyed with water, held to be baptized, and therefore they were remitted to baptism, as in Acts 2 when those three thousand had believed the Gospel and asked Peter what they should do, Peter did not pronounce them already baptized through the preaching of the Gospel, but said: “Repent, and let each one of you be baptized for the remission of sins.”

Now we must respond to their arguments. To the first therefore we respond: That in the Acts of the Apostles the disciples of Christ are described as having baptized in the name of Christ, this either savors of a compendious narrative of historical brevity, or expresses the organic author of this rite in the name (of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit) instituted and solemnly performed from His full omnipotence. For through Christ, God ordained this rite and commended it to the Apostles. That this is so is clear from Acts 19, where it is related that when Paul found disciples at Ephesus who had not only not received the Holy Spirit but had not even heard whether there was a Holy Spirit, he said in amazement: “Into what then were you baptized?”—signifying that they could not have been ignorant of the Holy Spirit who were baptized in the name of the Holy Spirit. Therefore baptism was conferred by the Apostles also in the name of the Holy Spirit. To the second we respond that negative expressions in Scripture are often to be taken comparatively: see an example of this in Matt. 12:7, 1 Cor. 9:9. And in this passage the words “He did not send me to baptize” ought to be understood thus: that is, not chiefly to baptize, but to evangelize; it is evident because Paul says in the same place that he not only evangelized but also baptized. Therefore Paul most clearly distinguishes evangelizing and baptizing, and therefore when the Lord sent the Apostles that they should teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, He did not mean the baptism of the Gospel and doctrine, but the baptism of water. For baptism was not divinely instituted, as the adversaries wish, that it should be merely a temporary rite, but that it should endure perpetually until the end of the world, which is most certainly and most clearly proved from Scripture. For after Christ, before His resurrection, had preached to the Jews only, as far as external and full ministry pertains, and had administered baptism through John and through His own disciples, after the resurrection from the dead He was wholly intent that by His ascension into heaven He might signify that He would not henceforth converse with men corporally in this age, yet through the Apostles and their successors He wills to gather to Himself a Church from every creature, that is, from the whole world, not only from the Jews but also from the Gentiles together. There, from the power given to Him, He instituted that both the doctrine of the Gospel and the use of baptism should be spread abroad and employed among the nations through the Apostles, Matt. 28:19, Mark 16:15-16. That our Lord Jesus Christ’s command the Apostles and the whole Church have diligently striven to fulfill from His ascension into heaven is clearly evident from Scripture, Acts 2:38 and 8:12 and 38 and 10:46-48. Writing also to the Ephesians about the year sixty of Christ, in chapter 4, Paul entreats that they walk worthily of the calling with which they were called, studying to preserve the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace. “For there is,” he says, “one body, one Lord, one faith, one baptism.” Thus Heb. 6:1-2, the foundations of Christian piety are named and enumerated: repentance from dead works, faith toward God, the doctrine of baptisms, laying on of hands, resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment. To us also has descended from the custom of the Apostles the manner and custom of baptizing, because when Christ was about to ascend to heaven, He sent the Apostles to the Gentiles, and together with the preaching of the word, He commanded that baptism should be administered and prevail among all and each of the nations. But since no command or trace of it has been shown by the adversaries up to this point that the use of water baptism ought to have been only for a certain time, this fiction is thrust upon us by them in vain.

C. The Identity of John’s Baptism in Substance: Of Its Institution, Object, and Efficacy

XII. John the Baptist, by God’s command, administered the same baptism in essence that the other Apostles did afterward.

TRELC. Since Scripture teaches that this baptism was administered by divine command, Luke 3:2-3, and is from heaven, Matt. 21:25, and that the Pharisees refusing it are said to have despised the counsel of God, Luke 7:30, baptism cannot be said to have been instituted by John himself. But that it is called the baptism of John distinguishes between the ministry of John himself and the magisterium of Christ.

WAL. The question is here whether the baptism of John and of Christ is the same baptism. The Papists deny it. We, although we concede that they differ in certain respects, nevertheless say that they agree in substance. I. Because the same external matter and internal signification, namely remission of sins, Mark 1:4, it is called “the baptism of repentance for the remission of sins,” and Acts 19:4. II. Because Christ was not baptized with another baptism; but it is not fitting that Christ, who ought to fulfill all righteousness, should have neglected this righteousness of the New Testament or not sanctified our baptism in Himself, just as He also sanctified the Lord’s Supper in Himself, and the sacraments of the Old Testament. III. Nor are the Apostles read to have been baptized with another baptism than John’s, nor John the Baptist himself, nor Apollos, Acts 18:25. And John and Christ’s disciples baptized at the same time, John 4:1. But it is not likely that two sacraments of different kinds endured simultaneously. For what the Papists feign, that Peter was baptized by Christ, the rest by Peter, lacks all Scripture, and conflicts with what is said, John 4:2: “Christ did not baptize.” Therefore what is said in John 3:22, that Christ baptized, is to be understood of His disciples.

Obj. He is not read to have baptized in the name of the Trinity. Resp. I. Nor are the disciples of Christ read to have baptized in the name of the Trinity before the resurrection; nevertheless it does not follow from this that it was not the same baptism. II. From the circumstances it can be gathered that he baptized in the name of the Trinity, as appears from the baptism of Christ, Matt. 3:16. For the Father speaks from heaven to His Son, and the Holy Spirit appears in the form of a dove. Then also this is gathered from his doctrine: for in his sermon which is extant in John 3:34, he says: “To this one,” namely to Christ, “God does not measure out the Spirit.” Finally, from Acts 19:4, where it is said that he baptized into Him who was to come, which involves the Holy Trinity.

2. Obj. But Paul rebaptized those who had been baptized by him, Acts 19:3. Resp. I. Not by him, but by certain disciples they had been baptized. II. Nor duly, because they did not know the Holy Spirit. III. From the text it is not proved that they were rebaptized; but it can be a continuation of Paul’s discourse, as the particles kai [Greek: and] and de [Greek: but] show.

MACC. We indeed assert that they were rebaptized, but because it had not been legitimately administered, inasmuch as it was administered to such adults who did not even know the principles of faith—for they were ignorant whether there was a Holy Spirit. Also because it was administered by such a one to whom this office did not belong, inasmuch as he had not used the form of the words of baptism, which Paul teaches was done wrongly when, with them responding that they did not know whether there was a Holy Spirit, he says: “Into what then were you baptized?”

D. The Material Cause of Baptism: The Outward Element and Rite

XIII. The matter of baptism is water.

GOM. Then the matter of baptism, or the subject thing which God instituted in it for signifying, according to the common nature of sacraments, is also contained in two members: substance and accidental rite. The substance is pure water, any water, because God so instituted it, John 1:33, Acts 8:26 (and therefore it is called kat’ exochēn [Greek: par excellence] the laver of water, Eph. 5:26, and by Tertullian, the sacrament of water, De bapt. c.1 and 12). Pure, because the thing signified, Eph. 5:26 (to which impure water is repugnant), and God demands such, Heb. 10:22-23. Any water, finally, since Scripture establishes no distinction. Therefore Tertullian rightly says: “There is no distinction whether one is washed in the sea or a pond, a river or a spring, a lake or a basin,” De bapt. c.4. But the rite attending the water is the dyeing and washing, or the ceremony of baptizing, from which member, synecdochically, baptism is called. But it matters little whether that ceremony is performed by one or threefold dipping, or even by immersion of the whole body or the head in water, or by pouring and sprinkling of water. It appears that Peter used this without fault in the baptism of the three thousand and of the five thousand at Jerusalem, Acts 4:4, and Paul when he baptized certain persons at home. For in both there is a certain immersion and staying under water, and washing and emerging, by which the ceremony of baptism is contained. Nor is this matter more strictly defined in the Holy Scriptures.

WAL. The essential sign is water, Matt. 3:11, Acts 10:47. Whence we gather that salt, spittle, oil, and if any other things are added here by the Papists beyond God’s command, are a profanation of this sacrament, since God is worshiped in vain by the commandments of men, Matt. 15:9, and to His commandments nothing is to be added nor taken away, as God commands, Deut. 12:32. But these adjuncts—salt, oil, etc.—arose from Old Testament sacrifices, from kakozēlia [Greek: bad zeal] of the Jews; the candle from the rite of the ancients, who when they gathered at night brought a candle, which was used in assemblies. The ritual or ceremonial sign is baptizing in the name of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, as is written in Matt. 28:19. But baptizing properly signifies washing or dyeing, as explained before; therefore it is called in Eph. 5:26 the laver of water in the word, loutron [Greek: washing], Tit. 3:5, and 1 Pet. 3:21, the putting away of the filth of the body.

Questions are moved here. I. Whether one ought to baptize by one or by threefold washing? Resp. This is judged indifferent in the Reformed Churches, some preserving this rite, others that: because Christ nowhere limited this or that, nor do the examples of the Apostles; some immerse once on account of the unity of the divine essence; others thrice on account of the trinity of persons.

2. Question. Whether one ought to baptize by sprinkling or by immersion? Resp. This also is judged indifferent, because examples of both are found in Scripture. As for immersion, the example of Christ seems to favor it, who entered into and came up out of the water, Matt. 3:16; likewise the Eunuch, Acts 8:38. Elsewhere sprinkling seems to be used, as in Acts 2:41, where many thousands are read to have been baptized by the Apostles in one day; likewise in private houses, Acts 16:33. Likewise the clinici [those baptized on a sickbed] in the early Church. The passage 1 Cor. 10:1 concerning the cloud and sea favors this, and the analogy of the sprinklings of old in the Old Testament, Heb. 9:13, where rhantismos [Greek: sprinkling] was used, and it is taught there and in 1 Pet. 1:2 that sprinkling with the blood of Christ corresponds to it analogically. And just as by the circumcision of the flesh of the foreskin, the whole man was considered circumcised, so a man baptized in one part of himself. Although therefore in the East and in warmer places the former rite was frequently used in the ancient Church, nevertheless the latter prevailed almost everywhere in the West and in colder places not without great reason, since everywhere the same analogy of sign and thing signified remains. Therefore the profanation of this sacrament consists in crosses, spittle, Papal exorcism, as if the infants of believers were possessed by Satan—which rite from energumens [those possessed by demons], and also from Gentiles who renounced Satan, has been badly transferred to others, without any example of Holy Scripture, much less a command.

To the external rite of baptism we refer the enunciation of the words of institution: in the name of the Father, etc., from Matt. 28:19, Mark 16:15. To be baptized in the name, or into the name, signifies: I. To be baptized by His command and authority, John 5:43: “I came in my Father’s name; if anyone comes in his own name,” etc. But eis onoma [Greek: into the name] seems to indicate more, namely to be adopted into the communion of the evangelical covenant by the Father in the Son through the Holy Spirit, or into the communion of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, as they were said to be baptized into the baptism of John, Acts 19:3—whence also the mutual stipulation of the covenant is understood.

Here the Scholastics anxiously dispute whether, if someone perhaps omits a syllable or pronounces it badly, the form of baptism would therefore perish. We respond that the form commanded by Christ must be altogether preserved, yet in such a way that Christ has bound His institution not to characters or syllables, but to the meaning itself. We acknowledge no other blessing of water than what the Papists are accustomed to use, because all these things are outside Scripture and are superstitious ethelothrēskeias [Greek: will-worship].

But the Apostles baptized in the name of Christ alone, as in Acts 2:38 and 10:48 and 19:4. Therefore this form is not necessary. Resp. The consequence is denied, because here not the form but the use of baptism is indicated, namely the transition into the new covenant, or into communion with Christ.

The internal matter is what constitutes the other part of the sacrament taken holōs [Greek: wholly]—the thing signified in baptism. To the elemental sign corresponds the blood of Christ, which cleanses us from all sin, 1 John 1:7, and washes us from our sins in His blood, Apoc. 1:5. Likewise the power of the Holy Spirit, Matt. 3:11. To the ceremonial or ritual sign corresponds purification from sins, on account of the blood, or the merit of Christ, and through the efficacy of the Spirit of Christ, as Paul explains, 1 Cor. 6:11 and 1 Pet. 3:21.

E. The Lawful Administrator of Baptism

XIV. The minister of baptism is the same as that of the Word, legitimately called to this.

TRELC. By the name “minister” we understand him to whom, in legitimate vocation, the ministry of the word has been committed. For the office of teaching the Gospel and administering the sacraments are joined together. Nor is it permitted for a private person, even in a case of necessity, to baptize, since there is no necessity which compels us to violate the orders prescribed by God, 1 Cor. 14:34. But the force and dignity of this ecclesiastical ministry does not depend on the quality of the minister, but on the power and truth of God who institutes it. For sacraments are true on account of the true God whose they are, Augustine says.

GOM. The administrator of baptism is he who baptizes from God’s vocation, namely the minister of the Gospel alone, because it is a proper part of that ministry, Matt. 28:19. Whence for the whole ministry, synecdochically, sometimes the word “baptism” is used, Acts 18:25. And therefore, what God has joined together, let not man separate, as is commanded by the general edict. But on the contrary, the apostate Roman Church teaches that an infant or catechumen, in danger of life, when the priest is absent, can be baptized both by a woman, Decret. causa 30.4.3 can. Super, and by a man, both by an unbeliever and by a believer. Concerning which, these consistent pronouncements of Bellarmine: “It is permitted for baptized laity, in a case of necessity, to baptize,” Tom.2 De bapt. l.1 c.7. Likewise, “It is permitted for the unbaptized, in a case of necessity, to give baptism, if they know the rite,” ibid. And Thomas Aquinas teaches the same, Sum. par. 3.9.67 art.5. Indeed, that even baptism conferred through play and childish amusement is true baptism, Bell. l.2 De bapt. l.1 c.7. And this he tries in vain to palliate by the example of the boy Athanasius (which some formerly rashly held as valid, Ruff. Hist. l.10 c.14), Tom.2 De sacr. l.1 c.28 and De pen. l.1 c.13.

WAL. Arg. I. Because Christ joined these two things in the institution of baptism, Matt. 28: “Go, teach all nations, baptizing them.”

Inst. But it is permitted to anyone to teach Christ, therefore also to baptize. Resp. It is permitted to any Christian to teach another privately, but it is not permitted to do so publicly as a preacher of the word unless called to it, either in an extraordinary or ordinary manner, as is seen in Heb. 5:4: “No one takes this honor to himself, but he who is called like Aaron.” Likewise 2 Cor. 5:20: only pastors are called ambassadors of Christ, who perform the embassy in Christ’s name. Now to administer sacraments is not a matter of private doctrine or an office of common charity, but an office of singular authority and public vocation. Just as it is permitted to any citizen privately to instruct a citizen concerning the public will of his magistrate; but to do this with public authority is permitted only to heralds or deputies of magistrates, just as neither is it permitted to affix the seals of magistrates to diplomas. II. Arg. To those pertains the administration of sacraments to whom pertains the oikonomia [Greek: economy] and dispensation of the mysteries of God. But to pastors pertains the dispensation of the mysteries of God, 1 Cor. 4:1, Tit. 1:7. The bishop is theos oikonomos [Greek: God’s steward] and presides over the house of God and has its care, 1 Tim. 3:5, Heb. 3:3. Therefore.

Inst. But the mysteries of God here are the word of the Gospel. Resp. I concede, but it is not the word alone, since sacraments are its appendices. Therefore these are to be understood conjointly, since they pertain to the care and rule of God’s house, and no one can seize for himself the office of steward or dispenser in any family unless from him who is set over the family, as Christ testifies, Matt. 18:23 and Heb. 3:6. III. Arg. If no example exists in the whole New Testament of anyone who administered baptism except a pastor and one called, then no one else can do this. But no such example exists. For John the Baptist, Christ’s disciples, John 4:2, baptized; Peter and the Apostles, Acts 2:41; Philip baptizes the Eunuch, Acts 8:38; Ananias baptized Paul, Acts 9:18; Paul and Barnabas baptized Lydia and the jailer with their households, Acts 16:15, 33; Paul baptized Crispus and Gaius and the household of Stephanas, 1 Cor. 1:14.

Inst. But Philip was a deacon; Ananias only a disciple of Christ. Resp. Nevertheless both were called to this in an extraordinary manner by God. II. It cannot be proved that Philip was still then a deacon, because he had already left Jerusalem and had gone to Caesarea; therefore he was an evangelist. A similar judgment is to be made about Ananias, who is therefore called mathētēs [Greek: disciple], Acts 9:10, which name was sometimes accustomed to be given to evangelists.

2. Inst. But Peter commanded that Cornelius with his household be baptized by his companions; but he himself did not baptize him. Resp. That etaxen autous baptisthēnai [Greek: he commanded them to be baptized], Acts 10:48, does not necessarily mean that they were not baptized by him, because it can be referred to the preparation for their being baptized. II. Even if it should be referred to the very act of baptism, it does not follow, however, that those who did it were laymen or idiots, since the Apostles almost always had some in their company who were evangelists or ministers of the word, whose ministry they would use. III. At least the command and apostolic vocation was present and gave them this authority. But the same arguments prove against the Papists and Lutherans that it is not permitted even in a case of necessity, as they wish; for they confess that ordinarily and outside a case of necessity this pertains to pastors; but they contend that in a case of necessity it pertains not only to laity but also to women. But beyond the superior arguments, the following also establish this: I. Because no one feigns such necessity in the sacrament of the Supper that it is permitted to celebrate it through another than through a pastor, since baptism no less than the Supper pertains to the dispensation of pastors. II. Because women are not even permitted to speak in the public assembly of believers, 1 Tim. 2:12, 1 Cor. 14:34—much less to administer sacraments. III. Because no necessity can be imposed upon us by which we should violate God’s law; as when God commanded that a male be circumcised on the eighth day, it was permitted to no one under the pretext of necessity to anticipate him; when God commanded that the Passover be celebrated on the 14th day of the first and second month, it was permitted to no one to change that day under any case of necessity. But the circumstance of person is as proper to the thing as that of time.

The example of Zipporah in the Old Testament, Exod. 4:25, does not prove this. I. Because then the tribe of Levi had not yet been separated from the other tribes, but it pertained to the fathers of families. II. Because she did this from indignation, and in the presence of her husband. But although the deed was approved insofar as God let Moses go, nevertheless He did not therefore praise the manner, just as the deed of the midwives is praised, but not the manner of the deed. Augustine, although here rather harsh, nevertheless sometimes acknowledges this, l.4 De bapt. c.24: “Then the sacrament of baptism is fulfilled invisibly when not contempt of religion but the crisis of necessity excludes that very thing.” Thus Ambrose in the funeral oration for the death of Valentinian who died before he was baptized. Thus Bernard, Ep. 37: “Contempt of the sacrament damns, not deprivation.” The same in Serm. 1 In Ram. Pal. col.116: “He who was born a little child and chose the first rank of little children does not today exclude little children from grace, because it is neither incongruous to His piety nor difficult to His majesty that He should supply the gift of grace which nature has less possibility of in them.” See also Bernard’s Letter 77, in which he cites many things from Ambrose and Augustine.

The absolute necessity of baptism is objected from John 3:5. Resp. I. There it does not treat of external baptism. II. If it is taken so, it must always be understood of legitimate baptism, and indeed according to God’s institution, as concerning circumcision.

The second question is whether the efficacy of sacraments depends on the worthiness or unworthiness of the minister. Resp. It depends not at all. I. The reason, from passages of Scripture, John 1:26: “I baptize in water, but in the midst of you stands one whom you do not know,” v.33: “This is he who baptizes in the Holy Spirit,” 1 Cor. 3:7: “Neither he who plants is anything,” etc. II. Because Judas and others also baptized according to Christ’s prescription, and yet Christ never called their baptism into doubt; and in the Old Testament many priests were impious. III. Because the efficacy of the word does not depend on the worthiness of the instrument, Phil. 1:16: “Some preach Christ from contention, not sincerely. What then? Provided only that in every way, whether in pretense or in truth, Christ is proclaimed, and in this I rejoice,” Matt. 7:22: “In your name we prophesied.” IV. The unbelief of men cannot make void the faithfulness of God, Rom. 3:2, and the consolation of believers cannot depend on man’s depravity but on God’s institution.

Inst. But at least a good intention of the one administering the sacraments is required: for thus the Papists wish. But what sort of intention is required, the Scholastics dispute sharply. Some require habitual, some actual, some virtual intention; some of doing what the Church does, some of administering the sacraments; some require also communicating the fruit of the sacrament—most consist in the last. Resp. A distinction must be made between those things which are required to constitute the full essence of the sacrament, and between those things which are required in the person of the minister, or for his faithfulness. In respect of the latter we concede that not only is due intention and attention required, that he who speaks should speak as the word of God, but also probity and piety; but although this may be lacking in the person, it is not therefore lacking in his ministry, nor does it cease to be a full and legitimate sacrament.

F. The Subjects or Recipients of Baptism: Adults Believing and the Infants of the Covenant

XV. But all who are received and enrolled into the covenant of God are to be baptized—not only those adults, but also their infants.

GOM. But God acknowledges as His covenanted ones, without distinction of sex, Acts 8:12, Gal. 3:27-28: first, adults professing faith and repentance by mouth and deed, Matt. 28:19 and 3:6; then infants begotten from at least one believing parent, 1 Cor. 7:14. This is also proved by the Orthodox against the Anabaptists by these arguments: I. Those to whom the promise of the covenant of salvation through Christ exhibited pertains are to be baptized; the infants of believers are such, Gen. 17:7, 1 Cor. 13:13, Acts 8:36, Matt. 19:14. Therefore they are to be baptized. Thus the Apostle Peter argued, Acts 2:39. II. Those to whom the Holy Spirit pertains, to them the water of baptism cannot be denied, Acts 10:47; the Holy Spirit pertains to infants, Acts 2:39, Matt. 19:14, Luke 18:15. Therefore the water of baptism cannot be denied to them. By this reasoning also the same Apostle argued, Acts 10:47. III. Those who pertain to Christ and His Church, to them also baptism is fitting, Eph. 5:26-27. The infants of believers pertain to Christ and to His Church no less than adults, Matt. 19:13-14, Acts 2:39, 1 Cor. 7:14. Therefore baptism is fitting for them. IV. The sacrament of the New Testament which succeeded in the place of circumcision is no less fitting now for infants than circumcision was formerly, because no less grace has been made to Christians than to Jews. But baptism succeeded in the place of circumcision, Col. 2:11. For each is a sign and seal of the covenant of grace through Christ, and a sacrament of initiation, as has been proved more fully before. Therefore baptism is fitting for infants. And therefore, since the reason is equal in both cases, it was not necessary for express mention of baptizing infants to be made.

MELANT. But that the baptism of infants is not a recent custom but is attested by the testimony of the early and purer Church, the following sentences show, which I will recite because I do not doubt that the pious are confirmed by the example of the purer Church. Origen in chapter 6 on Romans writes thus: “Therefore the Church also received a tradition from the Apostles to give baptism even to little children. For they knew, to whom the secrets of divine mysteries were entrusted, that there were in all the innate stains of sin which ought to be abolished through water and the Spirit.” These words of Origen contain clear testimony concerning two articles: original sin and the baptism of infants. Cyprian writes that in the Synod the opinion of someone was condemned who did not wish infants to be baptized before the eighth day. For the Synod decided that infants are to be baptized, nor ought the prescribed time of the eighth day to be observed. Augustine, De baptismo contra Donatistas, book 4, says concerning the baptism of little children: “What the universal Church holds, not instituted by Councils but always retained, is most rightly handed down as delivered by apostolic authority alone.”

JUN. And that this has been the perpetual custom of the Church, we have as witnesses Origen, l.5 on Rom. 6; Cyprian, l.3 Ep. 8; Jerome, l.3 Contra Pelag.; Nazianzen, Orat. in fanctum lavacrum; Basil, Orat. exhortatoria ad baptifmum; Augustine, l.1 De Gen. 3 and l.4 De bapt. c.24; and various councils: Conc. Milevit. Can.2, Gerundin. Can.5, etc.

The adversaries object that nowhere in Scripture is infant baptism commanded, nor does any example of baptized infants exist. Resp. Some things in the Scriptures are said explicitly and according to the letter; others implicitly, which are necessarily concluded from open testimonies of Scripture according to the analogy of faith. The baptism of infants agrees with the internal and spiritual truth of Scripture. For although we do not have an express command, nevertheless we have a general one concerning baptizing all the covenanted. But when the whole is posited, the parts are also necessarily posited, even if their singular enumeration is not made. Then, if there was a command under the law concerning circumcising infants, in it there will also be one concerning baptizing them, because since it is of perpetual right in the Church that the covenant should be sealed in infants, and since the old sacrament has been abolished, it is necessary that it be sealed with the new one which has succeeded in the place of the old. They require examples; but we assert that where there are laws and precepts, there is no need of examples, since proof which is made through rules is far superior to that which can be made through examples. Nor are they lacking, as we have already said, of entire households baptized by the Apostles without exception of infants. Finally we say that nothing is concluded from negative authority.

WAL. 1. Obj. Christ was baptized only when adult. Therefore we also. Resp. I. Thus it would follow that we ought to be baptized only in the 30th year. II. That was typical, because priests only in the 30th year fully undertook the execution of their priestly office in the temple, Num. 4:3; thus also Christ, entering upon His prophetic and priestly office, wished to be initiated into it through baptism and to begin the New Testament.

2. Obj. Christ says, Matt. 28:19: “Go, teach all nations, baptizing them.” Resp. I. Some respond that the word mathēteuein [Greek: to make disciples] signifies to make disciples, which is evident from John 4:1: “The Pharisees heard that Christ was making more disciples and baptizing than John,” where the word mathēteuein is explained by the phrase mathētas poiein [Greek: to make disciples]. II. Others say that from the order of speaking it cannot always be gathered what is to be done first or second; only that both are to be done can be gathered. And therefore it follows: “Teaching them to observe all things which I have commanded you,” v.seq. 20, as in Mark 1:4: “John was baptizing in the wilderness and preaching a baptism of repentance.” III. Nevertheless the best response is that Christ here immediately and properly sends the Apostles to adults who were to be converted and baptized.

Inst. But infants do not know what is being done. Resp. This does not matter, because even circumcised infants did not know what was being done, nor did those upon whom Christ laid hands, Mark 10:16, and yet it was not therefore in vain, because both God knows, and the Church for its consolation, and afterward they will know and acknowledge these benefits. Thus an infant is an heir and often affected by gifts and secured by seals for these things, and yet it is not therefore in vain. And in this way infants are more commended to the care of the Church, if they understand when already adult that they are thus in God’s care.

3. Obj. But Christ says, Mark 16:16: “He who believes and is baptized.” Therefore faith ought to precede. Resp. Either this passage treats only of adults, or if it is also to be understood of infants, then these infants also are to be counted among believers, because it is said: “He who does not believe will be condemned.”

But what is to be thought concerning the faith of infants, writers do not agree. Lutherans wish that they believe even with actual faith, although the evidence of the matter also compels them to confess that that actual faith is not such as that of adults, but is an inexplicable act. The opinion of Calvin and most other authors is pleasing. For thus Calvin in l.4 Inst. c.16 says that little children are baptized into future repentance and faith, which, although they are not yet formed in them, nevertheless the seed of both lies hidden in them by the secret operation of the Spirit. Thus also Ursinus, Sohnius, Bucanus, and most others think. We say therefore that infants (we now take them indefinitely, leaving God to His judgments) are to be counted among believers, because the seed or Spirit of faith is in them, which some call a habit, others an inclination, from which then through the hearing of the word actual faith is gradually formed, sometimes sooner, sometimes later; and yet we do not think this Spirit of faith to be without any act, because the Spirit is not idle, just as reason, although it does not exert itself except gradually, and indeed through instruction; just as we see that John the Baptist and Jeremiah leaped in the womb of the mother through the Spirit, although, as is probable, without knowledge and sense of what he did, as is clear from the fact that afterward John did not know Christ except from another sign of the dove descending upon Him. Augustine, Ep. 57: “Nor do I despise what was done in John, nor from it do I fix a rule what is to be thought concerning little children; indeed I proclaim that in him wonderfully because I do not find it in others.” For without faith it is impossible to please God; likewise, he who does not believe will be condemned; likewise, we are justified by faith. But infants please God, sins are remitted to them, etc. Therefore, if anyone wishes to restrict these sayings to adults, it must be demonstrated to him that there is some way of pleasing God without any faith, or regeneration without faith, which we have not yet found in Scripture. But the seed or Spirit of faith in infants causes them to be held as believers and members of Christ, and this relation which is in their faith to the merit of Christ is the instrument by which the merit of Christ, remission of sins, etc., is received. This is also demonstrated from this, that infants have the Spirit of Christ, Rom. 8:9, as pertaining to Christ; likewise that no one unless regenerated can enter the kingdom of God; likewise that nothing koinon ē akatharton [Greek: common or unclean] will enter the kingdom of God. But infants by their nature are unclean, and are purged through the blood of Christ, and the kingdom of heaven pertains to them, and they please God, etc. This is the safest and more common opinion, and most suitable for reconciling many passages of Scripture.

G. The Effects and True Efficacy of Baptism

XVI. The efficacy and power of baptism is not from the water or from the work of dyeing, but from the grace and promise of Christ, which are sealed to believers in the sacrament.

TRELC. The effects of baptism are not the deletion of all guilt and punishment, or the collation of grace ex opere operato [Latin: from the work performed], or finally the impression of an indelible character; but they are the same as its end explained above, of all of which the efficacy is not ascribed to external baptism or to the element of water, but to the blood of Christ and the internal baptism of the Spirit, which by secret operation confers that invisible grace which is figured by external baptism.

WAL. The Papists wish that baptism confers grace ex opere operato [from the work performed], that is, from the force of the administration itself, without respect to antecedent faith or repentance in the one being baptized, which they call opus operantis [the work of the one working]. But this also has been refuted above in general: both because it attributes justifying power to water, which belongs to the Spirit of Christ and His blood alone; and because it presupposes that those who are first regenerated are not in mortal sin, when even in infants original sin is mortal, not venial, as they themselves are compelled to acknowledge from Rom. 5:12 and 6:6, etc., Eph. 2:1; and because all adults, when they are first regenerated, must necessarily be considered as in the state of sin and its kingdom, as the passages John 3:5, 1 Cor. 6:11, Tit. 3:5, Eph. 2:5 teach. Tertullian, lib. de pænit. c.6 p.186 Pamel.: “That washing is the sealing of faith, which faith begins from and is commended by the faith of repentance. We are not washed that we may cease to sin, but because we have ceased, since we are already washed in heart; for this is the first dipping of the hearer, entire fear.” Therefore, with these opinions rejected as manifestly erroneous, the opinion of the Lutherans and certain Papists must be examined, who think that not indeed ex opere operato [from the work performed], but nevertheless from the force of the administration of baptism, together with baptism, the Holy Spirit always exerts this efficacy at the same moment in the baptized, so that just as He operates with the word, so also with external baptism; whence they also establish baptism as the ordinary means of regeneration in infants, and accordingly necessary in that manner. We indeed confess that the Holy Spirit ordinarily effects through baptism those things which are sealed in baptism, but we nevertheless deny that the action of the Holy Spirit is always bound to the act of baptism, just as it is not always bound to the act of preaching by the power of the word. And just as seeds cast into the earth do not always grow when they are committed to the earth, but when rain from heaven irrigates them and makes them fruitful, so it has seemed good to God in baptism. For the Spirit works where and when He wills, John 3:8. I. The reason is that in adults faith and repentance are manifestly required beforehand, and therefore also the beginning of regeneration, as is seen in Matt. 28:19 and Acts 2:38: “Repent, and let each one of you be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ for the remission of sins,” and v.41: “Those therefore who gladly received the word were baptized.” Examples are the Samaritans, Acts 8:12: “When they believed, both men and women were baptized”; the Eunuch, ibid. v.37: “If you believe with all your heart, it is permitted,” namely to be baptized. Thus Cornelius, Acts 10:47; Lydia and the jailer, Acts 16:15. II. From the example of hypocrites, who are indeed baptized according to the confession of their own mouth, nor yet are those effects of baptism conferred upon them, unless when, having laid aside hypocrisy, they begin to believe sincerely. Thus also those who were baptized by heretics, at least in adult age, as Augustine sometimes urges: “Although,” he says, “among heretics and schismatics the same is the baptism of Christ, nevertheless there it does not work remission of sins on account of the foulness of discord and the iniquity of dissension; but then the same baptism begins to avail for remitting sins when they have come to the peace of the Church, not that that baptism as alien or other is disapproved, or another is delivered, but that the same itself which outside worked death on account of discord, inside works salvation on account of peace.”

H. The Necessity of Baptism: Not Absolutely, But According to Divine Precept and Ordinary Means

XVII. Therefore also the necessity of baptism is not absolute, but of precept and of an ordinary means for the confirmation of grace.

JUN. Hence it is clear that external sacraments are not necessary simply, as the adversaries very badly say (Bell. l.2 De Sacr. c.4: “He who believes and is not baptized is damned”), but kata to sympheron [Greek: according to what is expedient] as a convenient means. For the privation of external baptism is not the privation of grace, but contempt; and while the will of baptism was not absent from the thief, but only the necessity of not receiving it was present, he was saved by faith alone, Aug. Contra Donat. l.4 c.22, as even Bellarmine confesses, De Sacr. l.2 c.23, as now also adults are justified by true faith before they have received the sacraments.

WAL. From all these things it is clear what is the necessity of sacraments: namely not absolute, but nevertheless of precept, when they can be had according to the order instituted by Christ; likewise of an ordinary means through which God wills to confirm faith and regeneration in us, as has been sufficiently proved before. But it is not absolute, because God sometimes supplies this defect both without the word, as in infants, and through the word alone in time of necessity in some adults, as is clear in the thief hanging on the cross with Christ.

POL. Ambrose consoles the sisters of Valentinian the second, the Emperor, who had departed from this life before receiving baptism, mourning on the ground that Valentinian had the desire to be initiated and had signified proximately that he wished to be baptized. And Ambrose adds: “Therefore does he not have the grace which he desired? Does he not have what he asked for? And because he asked for it, he received it.” Thus the thief converted on the cross obtained salvation without external baptism of water. For infants, baptism is necessary not simply for their invisible, but in a certain respect for their visible engrafting into Christ and the body of the Church, which if the crisis of necessity or impossibility of obtaining through external baptism excludes, is fulfilled invisibly without external baptism, which otherwise is demonstrated by invisible baptism.

MACC. For the necessity of baptism it is objected, John 3: “Unless one is born again,” etc. Resp. Peter Martyr responds excellently to this argument: for he says that force is not to be placed on the conjunction kai [Greek: and], as if water were necessary in the same way as the Spirit. For although the conjunction kai joins certain things, it nevertheless does not make them of the same condition and necessity. For Paul says: “With the heart one believes unto righteousness, and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation”; but who would say that there is equal necessity of confession and of faith? For one can be saved without confession, but not without faith; for one can deny Christ from fear and afterward repent.

I. The Unrepeatable Character of Baptism: Of Its Single Administration

XVIII. Finally, baptism once legitimately conferred ought never to be repeated.

WAL. The reason why baptism ought not to be repeated is the perpetuity of God’s covenant concerning remission of sins, as we have seen before. II. Because no command, no example of that thing exists in the New Testament. For the example in Acts 19:4 is of another kind and has already been explained before. III. From the example of circumcision, which once conferred was never repeated. For what they except, that it could not be repeated, first makes for us; then it is not absolutely true, because there were those who drew back the foreskin again, as Paul speaks, mē epispaesthō [Greek: let him not be uncircumcised], 1 Cor. 7:18. IV. Because initiation into the Church and regeneration is only one, and the new creature, just as there is one creation and one generation of man. Therefore also the laver of regeneration is one. Concerning the Supper it is said: “As often as you do this”; concerning baptism, never. V. Finally, the Apostle calls baptism one, both in the manner of signification and in the number of collation, Eph. 4:5.

1. Obj. But daily we have need of remission of sins. Therefore also of its sacrament. Resp. The consequence is denied, because this one sacrament seals the same grace to believers.

2. Obj. But those baptized by heretics and in infancy are not truly baptized. Therefore they are to be rebaptized. Resp. That the antecedent is false has been said in part before, in part will be proved afterward, with that distinction of heretics, however, which was produced before. Meanwhile, if anyone doubts the truth of his baptism, as concerning baptism conferred by midwives or laymen, or not conferred at all, legitimate baptism is not to be denied to him, as the example of those who were baptized in Acts 19:5 (according to some) by Paul shows. The Council of Carthage 5, in the year 403, congregated by 75 bishops, established this in chapter 3: “It has been decided concerning infants, whenever most certain witnesses are not found who testify without doubt that they have been baptized, and they themselves are not suitable by age to respond concerning the sacraments delivered to them, that they should be baptized without any scruple, lest this hesitation make them deprived of the purification of the sacraments.” Thus also Gregory, l.3 Ep. 4, and Leo, Ep. 35: “It cannot,” he says, “be called repeated which is not known to have been done.” And Lombard himself, 4 Sent. dift. 12 and 4. And therefore what is related by ecclesiastical histories concerning the boy Athanasius was superstitious. Nevertheless the Papists here use a certain caution, which I do not know whether it should be imitated, namely that they baptize conditionally: “If you are not baptized, I baptize you,” etc. But Luther rejects conditional baptism because it changes the form of baptism; then because it leaves the baptized uncertain.
