But how those who say that the grace of regeneration once truly accepted can be taken away and is often truly taken away defend the unity of baptism, I do not see, because a new regeneration would have need of a new sacrament, as we see in Adam before and after the fall.

MART. Whence, since circumcision was applied only once to each person, and there is only one nativity of each person, it follows that neither ought baptism to be repeated, which also happens because the Holy Spirit wills us to be thoroughly persuaded that after baptism we are not to return to the former life, as if a second regeneration could be granted.

III. Of the Sacrament of the Lord’s Supper

A. The Name, Etymology, and Essential Definition of the Lord’s Supper

XIX. The Holy Supper is the second sacrament of the New Testament, by which, through the solemn and sacred use of bread and wine, communion of the body and blood of Christ is sealed to believers.

JUN. This most sacred mystery has obtained various names: first, by reason of its matter; second, by reason of its circumstances. By reason of matter, threefold: first, from the heavenly matter of this feast, when namely Christ calls this mystery His body and blood, Matt. 26:26. Second and third, from the earthly and elemental matter: for it is called by Paul, 1 Cor. 10 and 11, bread and cup, etc., and a little afterward, the table of the Lord, by metonymy of the subject, namely for that sacred food and drink which is accustomed to be set on the table for the guests of the Lord. By reason of circumstances, various. First, it was imposed by the Apostle, calling it kyriakon deipnon [Greek: the Lord’s Supper], 1 Cor. 11, by which he makes allusion to that evening time in which our Lord, about to go to death, instituted this feast, substituting it for the celebration of the Passover, which was celebrated between the evenings according to the law. But this word “Supper” remains (for we do not delay over accidental circumstances) although it is celebrated in the morning time or at midday. It was then called by ecclesiastical writers synaxis [Greek: assembly] from the congregation of the Church which convenes at a certain time and place; eucharistia [Greek: thanksgiving] from the solemn rite of giving thanks for the whole work of our redemption; a sacrifice, not hilastikon [Greek: propitiatory], but mnēmosynon [Greek: memorial] of the sacrifice once performed, as Augustine rightly teaches, l.10 De civit. Dei c.5: “This visible sacrifice is the sacrament, that is, the sacred sign, of the invisible sacrifice.” Finally the Papists have called it the Mass, concerning the origin of whose name there is dispute among them. We, as we repudiate the Mass itself, so also the word, as in no way fitting for the matter which is now treated.

B. The Efficient Cause: Christ as Author, Institutor, and Pattern of Administration

XX. The author and institutor of the sacrament is Christ.

TRELC. The efficient cause of the Lord’s Supper ought to be considered either as instituting or as using and administering: the former principal, the latter serving or ministerial. The principal and instituting cause is the Lord, from whom the Lord’s Supper is customarily called—Christ namely panthrōpos [Greek: as man], the sole redeemer, instituting the mystery of His body and blood, by whose oblation He had redeemed us, Rom. 15:18, 2 Cor. 11:23. Of this mystical and divine institution there are two parts: the deed of Christ and His words, of which by the former He concluded and left an example of administration; by the latter, the doctrine of institution. Of the deed of Christ, by which the manner of legitimate leitourgias [Greek: liturgy] or administration is explained, there are three parts, as Christ employed sacred and ceremonial actions in order concerning both symbols which He took. The first is sylogia [Greek: blessing] and eucharistia [Greek: thanksgiving], blessing and giving of thanks. For Scripture uses two words: that in Matt. 26:26 and Mark 14:22, this in Luke 22:19 and 1 Cor. 10:24, both signifying one and the same thing—how namely Christ, by prayers to God, by giving of thanks, and by that whole sacred action, prepared, destined, and sanctified the bread and wine for sacred use, that they might be the sacrament of His body and blood, not by their own nature but by divine institution. And this is that true consecration or sanctification of the sacrament, of which mention is made among the Fathers. The second is the breaking of bread and the pouring of wine into the cup, which Christ used not only for the sake of dividing or distributing, but for the sake of representing His death. For it is an essential and sacramental ceremony of the Lord’s Supper, pertaining to its end and form. The third is the exhibition and distribution of the broken bread and poured wine. For Christ did not give to His disciples that they might distribute, but that they might receive what was distributed. For they were in that Supper not dispensers of the mysteries of God, but guests. But Christ, as host, by the same work both instituted and dispensed with His own hands the sacrament of His grace, and at the same time sanctified its ministerial dispensation. And all these actions are sacramental and ought to be considered schetikōs [Greek: relatively], insofar as they were employed for signifying and sealing spiritual things by divine ordination. To these actions (that we may come to the second part of institution), Christ joined words, of which some include a command, others a promise, others finally an explanation: those preceptive, others ping [?] and sacramental, these finally exēgētika [Greek: explanatory], as they are customarily called in the schools. The preceptive are those by which He enjoined upon both dispensers the necessity of their administration, and upon communicants the necessity of reception, and prescribed the form of each to both. Of administration indeed, by His deed, concerning which it was said above, and by the adjoined command of imitation, Matt. 26:26, 1 Cor. 11:24. But of communion by a twofold precept: one of receiving, the other of eating and drinking, Mark 14:22. Reception is a sacramental rite prescribed to one approaching the table of the Lord, by which we receive the bread or the eucharistikon [Greek: blessed] cup with the hand (for neither from the history of the institution of the Lord’s Supper nor from the form of reclining of Christ and His Apostles can it be gathered that Christ in the first Supper put those signs into the mouths of individual Apostles), by which reception both the spiritual sealing of Christ Himself and of His benefits within us is declared through the instrument of faith. Eating and drinking is the external and sacramental use and assumption of the signs according to Christ’s prescription, by which the internal and spiritual eating of the body and blood and the draught is sealed by divine ordination. For just as first there are two persons administering the Supper: one of the Pastor, doing that which is done externally and outwardly; the other of Christ, effecting by His Spirit that which is done internally; second, the whole action of the Lord’s Supper consists of two things: one earthly, corporeal, and perceptible to the senses; the other heavenly, spiritual, and intelligible to the mind of believers; third, there are two parts of man: one the body, the other the soul—so there are two diverse exhibitions and eatings: one external, which is called sacramental; the other internal, which is spiritual; the former, however, instituted by Christ that it might be a certain express image of the latter. The iesin [?] and sacramental words are those which declare the internal matter, or thing signified, and enunciate it sacramentally, whether concerning the bread or concerning the cup. Concerning the bread indeed: “This is my body, which is delivered for you and broken,” Luke 22:19. But concerning the cup: “This is my blood which is poured out for many,” Matt. 26:28. Both these enunciations are customarily considered in two ways: either in individual words considered separately and by themselves, or in the whole enunciation. Considered separately, they denote either subject, or attribute, or copula. The subject is the demonstrative pronoun (hoc [this]), taken not adjectively but substantively. For it does not signify some vague or evanescent individual, but the bread itself which Christ took, broke, and gave to His disciples, and the wine which He held in His hands, as the series of the text, Matt. 26:26-27, the Pauline interpretation, 1 Cor. 11:24-25, and the analogy of faith demonstrate. The attribute in the first enunciation is the body of Christ—not the mystical, which is the Church, but the proper and true, which is delivered and broken for us, and that as such; in the second it is the blood of Christ which is poured out for us, and that as such, as the other member of this attribute, which is enunciated through diamayi [?] of the present tense for the future, most clearly proves. The copula by which the attribute is joined with the subject is the substantive verb “is,” which ought not and cannot be taken hyparkikōs [Greek: substantially] and substantially, since by no reason at all can a disparate thing be said properly and essentially of a disparate thing, but figuratively for mystical and sacramental being, by which the thing which signifies receives the name of that thing which it signifies, on account of the analogy of one to the other. For Christ did not teach by that little word what the bread and wine were by nature and substance, but what they were by signification, office, and use. By nature indeed, they are bread and wine; by signification, they are the body and blood of Christ. The whole attribution or predication is not proper or regular, since neither is the proposition identical, nor can body be said properly of bread (inasmuch as the body of Christ is neither the genus, nor species, nor difference, nor property, nor accident of bread), but figurative and sacramental. Figurative indeed, not simply metaphorical and allegorical, but metonymical—such namely as that by which the name of the thing signified is attributed to the sign; which metonymical speech is very familiar to the Scriptures. Sacramental, because at the same time the exhibition of the thing signified is promised, nor yet is there departure from the very to rhēton [Greek: what is said], since we retain the sacramental to rhēton [what is said], which is altogether dissimilar to regular predications and is to be explained by fitting interpretation according to the nature of sacraments. The exēgētika [explanatory] words are those by which Christ expounded the end of this sacred action, namely the commemoration of His death, 1 Cor. 11:11, 26, which is not a bare or idle recollection of a past event, but an efficacious and salutary apprehension of the merit of Christ and kat’ idian [Greek: individual] application, and at the same time a solemn eucharistikē [Greek: thanksgiving], in the use of this sacrament, for so great a benefit on account of so great a benefit. And this is the account of the principal efficient cause, or that which institutes the Supper, and of the institution itself.

C. The Material Cause: The Outward Elements and the Inward Thing Signified

XXI. The external matter of the sacrament is bread and wine; the internal or thing signified is the body and blood of Christ.

JUN. The matter is twofold, as we may speak with Irenaeus (l.4 c.34), one earthly, the other heavenly; the first is bread and wine, the second the body and blood of Christ. That we commonly designate by the name of sign, through which invisible things (not by their own nature) are represented to us according to the capacity of our weakness—for a sign, since it is from the genus pros ti [Greek: in relation to something], always makes something else come into thought than what it is itself; but this we designate by the name of the thing signified, which is that thing which to us believers is at the same time figured and exhibited through the symbols. But as the matter is twofold, so the instrument of perceiving the matter is twofold: one visible and corporeal, namely the mouth of the body; the other invisible and spiritual, namely faith. For it is established that a fitting instrument is required for perceiving any thing; then, that everything is received according to the manner of the one perceiving. But since the body and blood of Christ are spiritual food and drink for us, they cannot be perceived by the corporeal mouth but by the spiritual. Therefore it is said in vain that the body of Christ is placed in our mouth, that as if by that door being opened it might enter into our soul, since faith alone is the door by which Christ enters into our souls, Eph. 3:17: “By faith,” it says, “Christ dwells in our hearts.” Nor does what is objected stand: If the eating of the body of Christ is understood spiritually, the body of Christ is no longer a body but a spirit. For a distinction must be established between the thing itself and the mode of participation. We acknowledge indeed that the body of Christ is a true body after glorification, as it was before, nor has that taken away anything from it as to its being. Then we say that the body of Christ is the food of our souls, and has the character of food, not because it is a corporeal substance, by which manner it would be corporeal food, but insofar as the body of Christ is given for the life of the world. Third, we assert that this does not prevent the mode of participation from being spiritual (not however imaginary, as the Papists falsely calumniate) and true. For the eating of the body of Christ is nothing else than the most close conjunction with Christ: “He who eats my flesh and drinks my blood remains in me, and I in him,” John 6:56. Bede explains this passage excellently, in John c.6: “This is,” he says, “to eat that food and to drink that drink: to remain in Christ and to have Him remaining in oneself. Therefore does he not remain in Christ, and in whom Christ does not remain? He does not eat His flesh spiritually, although carnally and visibly he may press with his teeth the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ, but rather eats and drinks the sacrament of so great a thing to his judgment.”

WAL. Concerning these signs it is asked: I. Whether unleavened bread ought to be used? We concede that Christ in the first Supper used unleavened bread, because the days of unleavened bread had already come, Matt. 26:17, and accordingly it was not permitted to use other bread at the time of Passover. But we assert nevertheless that we are not obligated to such bread, as the Greek Church has constantly defended against the Latin Church, although the Greeks seem afterward to have fallen into another extreme, because they judged that only leavened bread ought to be used. I. The reason is that Christ then used common bread and that received in common use, nor did He adjoin any precept of preserving such bread. II. Because Acts 20:7 and elsewhere it is called the breaking of bread, and 1 Cor. 11:23 Paul makes mention only of bread, customary and usual; indeed, neither among the Jews nor the Gentiles was it customary to use unleavened bread outside the times of that feast. III. Because the precise observance of unleavened bread was typical, 1 Cor. 5:7. Therefore, since with that intention of precise observance we ought not to use it, nothing prevents free use.

WEND. But why we do not use round hosts, which they commonly call oblates, and likewise wafers of bread in the Lord’s Supper, these are the reasons: I. Because Christ did not employ such wafers of bread in the institution and administration of the first Supper, but ordinary bread and that received in common use. II. Because the Roman Pontiffs, against Christ’s institution, instituted hosts in place of alimentary bread in the Lord’s Supper, after they persuaded the rude people that the bread is transmuted into the body of Christ, and transformed the Lord’s Supper into a sacrifice; whence the Church of Christ cannot use them without great scandal. III. Because these hosts or wafers are not true and alimentary bread, and accordingly do not have the analogy with the body of Christ which we have explained above, which we prove: I. Because they do not have the proximate matter of bread, that is, flour and water so prepared and disposed as true and ordinary bread requires. For in order that true and ordinary bread be made from water and flour, not any sort of preparation of it suffices, and mixture of these two material principles, but it is required: 1. That they be mixed in just quantity, so that a solid, substantial substance may result from it, suitable for nourishing men. II. That they be thoroughly kneaded and cooked with labor, and thence obtain flavor and odor fitting for bread and pleasing to man—none of which is found in hosts, which lack just substantiality, flavor, and odor. II. Because they do not have the form of ordinary bread, which is clear from this: that their matter does not have the dispositions which the form of true and ordinary bread requires, as we have just shown. III. Because they do not have the end and effects of true and ordinary bread: for they do not nourish and strengthen the body, nor are they used for other foods, but rather harm our bodies and hinder digestion; whence they are not admitted to feasts, and are prohibited by physicians as harmful to health.

The Lutherans and Papists except: Bread is not given in the Eucharist that it may nourish the body. Therefore the power of nourishing is not necessarily required in it. Resp. I deny the consequence; the reason is that the power of nourishing is required, not that it may nourish our bodies in the use of the Lord’s Supper, but that it may represent and seal the power of the body of Christ in spiritually nourishing our souls, which certainly it does not furnish if it has no power of nourishing in itself. Thus unless the water of baptism had the power of washing away corporeal filth, it would not be a suitable symbol of the blood of Christ washing away spiritual filth, that is, sins. For the same reason, true and natural wine also is used in the Lord’s Supper. For unless sacramental symbols had a certain analogy with the things signified, they certainly could not truly be called sacraments, as Augustine testifies.

WAL. Another question is whether pure wine or that mixed with water ought to be used? Resp. This also is indifferent, because Holy Scripture asserts nothing here. Although we confess it agrees better with the words of Christ if pure wine is taken, both because in Matt. 26:29, Mark 14:25, what was in the cup is expressly called the fruit of the vine, and because there is a better analogy between wine, which is made from diverse grapes, shadowing forth the unity of Christians, as Paul gathers, 1 Cor. 12:13: “We were all made to drink into one Spirit”; 1 Cor. 10:27: “There is one bread, so also we, being many, are one body.”

Inst. But in the East pure wine is rarely drunk. Therefore Christ also used mixed wine. Resp. I. Although we should concede this, nevertheless it does not follow that in that place where wines are more diluted and the temperature warmer, it ought not to be used. II. Perhaps in common drink it was not customary, but in mystical use it was nevertheless customary.

Inst. But from the side of Christ flowed blood and water. Therefore both ought to be used in the Supper. Resp. I. Blood and water, as John explains, 1 Ep. 5:6, signifies that Christ came in blood and water, that is, not only to remit sins but also to purge them. Likewise blood, water, and spirit give testimony concerning Christ, that is, the certainty of remission of sins, the renewal of man, and the testimony of the Spirit in our hearts. II. Others, like Augustine, wish here to understand both sacraments, namely baptism and the Supper. III. The sign is not the thing signified. But here we are treating of the thing signified.

D. The Formal Cause: The Sense of the Words “This is my body” as Sacramental and Figurative

XXII. The words of the Supper, “This is my body,” are not to be taken properly but figuratively and sacramentally.

JUN. It follows that this enunciation, “This is my body,” is not to be taken simply and according to the letter, for if this is posited, many absurdities would follow—we will be content with one, however: namely, if this enunciation is to be taken according to the letter, it is an identical proposition; if identical, therefore the terms are convertible, and accordingly, as rightly you would say, “This is my body,” so vice versa, “My body is this”—than which nothing is more absurd. It is therefore figurative, and that from the use of sacramental enunciations, such as these are: “The cup is the new testament in my blood,” Luke 22:20; “Circumcision is the covenant,” Gen. 17:10; “The lamb is the passover,” Ex. 12:43; “The rock is Christ,” 2 Cor. 10:4.

GOM. The question is whether there is a trope in these enunciations or not. The Orthodox uphold the former, who agree in the thing itself, and thus declare: This bread is the sacrament or sign of the body of Christ, or signifies the body of Christ—which (as even the Jesuits acknowledge, Bellar. De Euchar. l.1 c.11, Stapleton, Antid. in Matt. 26) come to the same thing and mutually follow one another. Nevertheless, in defining the seat of the trope, they differ in judgments. Some dispute that in these and other tropical enunciations, individual words retain their proper signification, and the trope consists not in the copula alone, nor in the attribute alone, but in the whole attribution, because a disparate thing is affirmed directly of a disparate thing in them. Others judge that the trope consists in the copula “is,” placed for “signifies.” But it is best established in the attribute; but it is a certain metonymy, most common in the divine explanation of sacraments, by which the name of the thing signified is put for the sign of it.

PROF. Concerning the seat of the trope, there is variation of opinions among the Orthodox, although they nearly agree in the sum of the matter. Some wish there to be a trope in no part, neither in the subject, nor in the predicate, nor in the copula. For each of these is taken properly. But the predication is figurative. Thus after Zanchius, Beza. Indeed Crellius opposes a figurative logical proposition to rhetoric, and defines the former by the whole enunciate, the latter by voice. But since logic is of the mind and internal reason, not of speech, there is no figurative predication of it, but only a figure of rhetorical elocution. And although its cause is from the attribution, nevertheless the seat is in some certain part. Others therefore establish the trope in the subject, or in the demonstrative voice “This,” like Bucer, so that by it bread with body and wine with blood are signified on account of the sacramental union, by which nevertheless it is not necessary that both be constituted substantially present, but only really, so that to the sense bread and wine, to the mind the body and blood of the Lord is demonstrated. And thus they say it happens in all speeches by which through signs insensible or absent things are promised and exhibited; the sense would therefore be: This, which I give to you by this sign, is my body, etc. But there is no prior mention made of the body that it might be demonstrated by “This,” and the declaration of that union is first made through these words. Others place the trope in the word “Is,” taken for “signifies,” thus after Honius the Dutchman, Zwingli. And certainly “is” among other significations is not rarely taken for “signifies,” as when interpreting words from one language into another we say “it is,” which is worth, signifies. Matt. 1:23. And concerning things: the seven ears and seven cows are seven years, Gen. 40:13, 19 and 41:26; the seed is the word of God, the field is the world, Matt. 13:37-38; the seven stars are seven angels, etc.; the many waters are many people, Apoc. 1:20 and 17:15. Likewise for “to be similar,” as: I am that bread, the true vine, the door; John is Elijah; Herod is a fox—where there is metaphor in the predicate. To which they also refer those sacramental expressions: Circumcision is the covenant; the lamb is the passover; the rock was Christ; the cup is the New Testament. Nevertheless these bring not only signification and similitude but also sealing and exhibition. But “is” has partly the character of the predicate, partly of the copula, as is clear from the resolution of the word. Others finally, with Oecolampadius, place the trope in the word “body” and “blood,” and then “Is” will be only a bond, and the sense will be: bread and wine is the symbol, seal, sealing, pledge, earnest, exhibition of the body and blood. This opinion is confirmed by this most firm argument: Into whichever part the analysis [Greek: resolution] or resolution of a tropical expression into a proper one falls, in that is the trope. But it falls into the words “body” and “blood,” with the nominative case changed into the oblique. For as “circumcision is the covenant” is resolved into this: “is the sign of the covenant,” so “bread and wine is the body and blood of Christ” is resolved into these: “is the communion of the body and blood of the Lord”—not by which the bread, but by which believers have communion with the body of Christ. Therefore the trope is rightly constituted in the predicate. Nevertheless it does not follow from this that the truth of the body and blood of Christ is removed from the Supper, and a tropical and symbolic body and blood are introduced, against that: “This is my body which is broken for you; this is the blood which is poured out for you”—which argument indeed the Papists after Scotus, and those from Luther, urge as paramount. But it is one thing for there to be a trope in the word “body,” and another for the body to be tropical; one thing a symbol of the body, and another a symbolic body. The former leaves the truth of the body; the latter removes it. And certainly by such a trope what is, is not denied, but something else is moreover assigned to it, and it embraces both. Whence Cajetan on Thomas, to the argument of Scotus, rightly responds that the true body is not removed even if a trope is established, as when it is said: “The rock was Christ,” that is, the symbol of the true Christ, to be born from the virgin Mary, to be crucified, to be killed, etc. Thus also here—for it is one thing to ask what sort the predicate is, and another how it inheres in the subject. But the kind of trope is also clear from this: to be namely metonymy, which Augustine also acknowledges, with the thing signified put in addition for the sign, and indeed analogical, that is, bearing a proportionate similitude to the thing signified. For as Augustine says: “Unless sacraments had similitude of those things of which they are sacraments, they would not even be sacraments.” Nor is that only, but they are signs of such a kind to which present, conjoined, and united in their own manner (namely sacramentally, that is, really indeed, namely schetikōs [Greek: relatively], not however substantially) are the things signified, the body and blood of the Lord; indeed they are changed, as the Fathers speak, not in substance and nature itself, but in condition, use, and office. Indeed, moreover, they are as it were vehicles, instruments, through which is exhibited or offered to all, but to believers is conferred, given, and taken by the faithful, the very body and blood of Christ, which is proper and native to the sacrament. By which phrase the Apostle says the Gospel is the power of God unto salvation to everyone who believes, and the bread which we break, that is, the breaking and eating of bread, is the communion of the body of Christ. Whence Christ rather said, “This is my body” and “This is my blood,” improperly attributing to bread and wine the name of body and blood, and that in what is predicated, as if it were an essential enunciation, than He wished to use the proper kind of speech—namely on account of the clear signification, highest similitude and analogy of these signs to the thing signified, the sealing, confirmation, certainty, certification, exhibition, and collation through these signs of the thing signified (for these words have an included promise of the thing made by God and added to the external signs, which from God’s side is offered to all, from our side is perceived by faith) than which emphasin [Greek: emphasis] and energeian [Greek: energy] of the meaning no proper enunciation whatsoever attains. And in this sacramental schesei [Greek: relation] and disposition consists the essential form of the Lord’s Supper. Wherefore the Papist Transubstantiators and other Consubstantiators who assert that these are proper enunciations err gravely. Nor do they truly say this which Scripture says, as their interpretation indicates. For it is not asked what is made from the bread, or where the body and blood of Christ is or hides, whether under bare species or under bread and wine, which really is to make predicates from subjects. Then, since by “this” they understand either the external species of bread and wine, as they do, or bread and wine, as these do, and under them, as contents, they comprehend the body and blood of the Lord, they necessarily introduce synecdoche in the subject. Finally, since they attribute to them the character of signs besides, without which there is no sacrament, which cannot be done without certain words of institution (for they are signs from institution) declaring the act of signifying, which are no others even from their mind than “This is my body, this is my blood,” so that the character of the predicate to the subject may be adequate, they must, whether they will or not, acknowledge metonymy in the predicate, unless they overturn all character of the sacrament and sign. Nor with the Papist Transubstantiators is “This” understood as a vague individual, as Thomas wishes: for “This” demonstrates something certain and present; or some singular or individual of a more general substance, which with the predicate refers the same, or as Scotus speaks, supposes for the same, so that those things which are signified by subject and attribute do not differ among themselves except by various modes of conceiving, so that the sense would be: This content under the species of bread and wine is my body and blood—for thus the enunciation will be identical in the thing itself, and the sign overturned; or also that which bread and wine was before, for only after the words are uttered, from the common opinion of the Papists, bread and wine becomes, and thus is the body and blood of the Lord; nor finally the species or accidents of bread and wine, namely color, odor, taste, and figure, without a proper subject and hanging in the air—for this truly is to remove the truth of the signs and to suppose phantastic and delusory things. Nor with the Consubstantiators or Impanators (into which opinion many Scholastics, like Scotus and Aliaco, etc., incline, about to embrace it unless the authority of the Lateran Synod, held in the year 1215, had restrained them; whence Luther also borrowed it) will “this” signify in, with, or under this, or here, that is, bread and body, wine and blood—since bread is not suitable for receiving the body, nor can the body go under it, both being compact and unequal, and wine is not something under which another liquid can hide, both flowing from its own terminus and mixing among themselves. Indeed, what is not attended to here is the comprehension of a thing under another, but signification and exhibition, that is, not where or under what the body and blood of the Lord is, which is to make the predicate from the subject and vice versa, but what is that bread and wine.

E. Rejection of a False Material Change: No Transubstantiation of Bread into Christ’s Body

XXIII. No transubstantiation of bread into the body of Christ occurs in the sacrament.

URSIN. By no means is the nature of bread and wine changed into the substance of the body and blood of Christ. I. Because Paul expressly names bread and wine as that which is taken: “The bread which we break”; “He who eats unworthily of this bread.” II. Nor are signs physically changed into things signified, nor things into signs. For signs are perceived by the members and senses of the body, but things signified by faith alone. Nor do spiritual gifts pass into corporeal things or are made from them, Rom. 14: “The kingdom of God is not food and drink.” Whoever denies this principle of Christian doctrine, we leave to himself. Augustine, In Joan. hom.26: “For we also today receive visible food, but the sacrament is one thing, the power of the sacrament another. How many receive from the altar and die, and by receiving die! Whence the Apostle says: ‘He eats and drinks judgment to himself.’“ Gelasius, Cont. Eutych. and Nest.: “The sacraments which we receive of the body and blood of Christ are divine things, on account of which also through them we are made partakers of the divine nature; and yet the substance or nature of bread and wine does not cease.”

F. Rejection of a Corporeal Inclusion: No Consubstantiation of Christ’s Body with the Bread

XXIV. Likewise there is no consubstantiation of the body of Christ with the bread.

URSIN. Nor does the human nature or body and blood of Christ hide or is invisibly present in or under the bread and wine, or in the place of the bread and wine, nor does it lie immense, is borne in hands, is received by mouth and teeth, etc., but all these things belong only to the signs. But Christ is eaten by faith alone, that is, the communication of Christ is not corporeal but only spiritual, which is made by the motion of the Holy Spirit, namely by faith, and by the Holy Spirit dwelling in us. Believers indeed eat simultaneously the bread and Christ, but the bread in its own manner, Christ likewise in His manner; they receive the bread by mouth, they are engrafted into Christ by faith. Such eating of Christ and no other, properly speaking, outside the Supper and in it, antiquity acknowledges, as Augustine, In Joan. Tract. 25: “Why do you prepare teeth and belly? Believe, and you have eaten.” The same, In Joan. Tract. 26: “This is to eat that food and to drink that drink: to remain in Christ and to have Him remaining in oneself.” Chrysostom, In serm. de Euch. in encæ.: “When approaching these mysteries, do not think that you receive the divine body from man.” Eusebius Emissen., In ser. de Euch.: “When you ascend to the venerable altar to be satisfied with spiritual foods, look upon the sacred body and blood of your God with faith, wonder with honor, touch with the mind, receive with the hand of the heart, and assume with the greatest draught of the interior man.” Hilary, l.8 De Trin.: “These things received and drunk effect that both we are in Christ and Christ is in us.”

G. The Mode of Presence: Christ’s Body in Heaven and His Spiritual Presence in the Supper

XXV. For the body and blood of Christ is not present substantially or corporeally in the Supper, nor is it omnipresent.

URSIN. But this proposition, “Christ is or is present or is present in the Supper,” is diversely taken. If it is understood concerning the presence of Christ on earth in that place where bread and wine are taken, it is true concerning Christ according to the divine nature. And then if it is said concerning the place of the bread or any other place outside believers, it embraces only general presence; but if we understand Christ to be present in the Supper in those legitimately using it, that presence is special. But since the Supper is an action, this proposition properly signifies not so much presence in a certain place, as that Christ is efficacious through this visible reception, and in it, that is, at that time when bread and wine are taken, communicates Himself to believers, with both natures acting and present, as and where the property of each requires, that is, according to the divine nature present everywhere by merit, efficacy, and indwelling, which embraces copulation; according to the human nature remaining in heaven, by merit and copulation which is made by the mediation of the Holy Spirit. If the proposition is so understood, not concerning local presence but concerning communication, it is true simply. Because the whole person of Christ is communicated to us, but with the property of each nature preserved. And the same will be the meaning of these expressions: Christ is in the Supper; Christ communicates Himself in the Supper; Christ is efficacious in the Supper; Christ is present spiritually or by faith in the Supper. And so understood this also will be true: The body of Christ is present in the Supper, that is, is communicated to us, namely by faith or spiritually, by merit and copulation. Thus it can be present and communicated to us even while remaining in heaven, since the communication of Christ is an action which is performed simultaneously in heaven and on earth: for Christ, existing in heaven simultaneously and on earth according to the divine nature, in heaven according to the human, communicates Himself to us existing on earth.

WEND. Let it be noted briefly that the corporeal presence of the body of Christ in, with, and under the bread, or the appearance of bread, conflicts: I. With the nature of sacraments in general—for sacraments are not vessels of grace or of things signified, but only signs and seals. II. With the first institution and administration of the Supper. For when Christ took bread from the table, broke it, and distributed it, He sat at table together with His disciples; but He was not in, with, and under the bread, nor did He break Himself in, with, and under the bread, nor did He bear Himself in His hands. III. With the end of the instituted Supper, which Paul says is that we should remember Christ and announce His death until He comes to judgment. But if He is already present in His body, the announcement of His death will cease. IV. With the scope and intention of Christ. For Christ wished to be eaten by believers principally as to His body, insofar as it was delivered and crucified for us. Whence He says: “This is my body which is delivered for you.” But those who now feign corporeal presence in the bread and establish oral eating, they exhibit for eating only the glorious and impassible body. It was also the scope of Christ to instruct His disciples concerning the truth and fruit of His future passion. But how could the truth of the passion be persuaded to them if so great a scruple concerning the truth of the body had been cast in, namely that the body of Christ is so constituted that in, with, and under the bread it is invisible, impalpable, devoid of human figure and dimensions, indeed not even comprehended in a certain place? Who would believe that such a body can truly suffer? V. With the nature of a true and human body, which is visible, palpable, and circumscribed in a certain place—such as that body is not which is feigned under the host in many places simultaneously. The adversaries except: It does not conflict that it is finite, circumscribed, and simultaneously not except in one place, and nevertheless to be in many places simultaneously; for the former belongs to the body of Christ naturally through the power of nature, the latter supernaturally and in a mystical manner. R. What overturns the nature of a true, human, and finite body, such as polyopia [Greek: multilocation] or ubiquity is, cannot belong to a true, finite, and human body, either naturally or supernaturally or mystically. Thus it can in no way happen, even in respect, that a man is and remains a man, and yet is not endowed with reason. Therefore if the true, finite, and natural body of Christ is mystically and supernaturally in many places simultaneously, or everywhere, certainly mystically and supernaturally it will not be the true, not finite, not natural body of Christ. VI. With the nature of the glorious body of Christ, which can no longer suffer or die, and accordingly cannot be eaten corporeally and orally. But these feign that the glorious body existing corporeally in the bread is eaten orally and suffers whatever the bread suffers, as the express words of Luther have. Or, if they do not feign this, which many acknowledge to be absurd, in this part they are not gnēsioi [Greek: genuine], disciples of Luther, nor can they defend oral and properly so-called eating. VII. With the ascension into heaven and remaining there until the last day. For if Christ ascended into heaven as to His body, and remains there until the last day, certainly He is not now on earth and in the bread in His body; or if He is, it is false that He ascended into heaven and remains there until the last day. VIII. With express testimonies of Scripture which deny that Christ is always in these lands in His body. Such are: “I came into the world, I leave the world again,” that is, the earth, John 16:28; “You will not always have me with you,” John 12:8; “If He were still on earth, He would not be a priest,” Heb. 8:5.

H. The Mode of Participation: No Corporeal or Oral Eating of the Body of Christ

XXVI. Likewise there is no oral eating of the body of Christ in the Supper.

WEND. The Papists and Lutherans, not content with the spiritual and sacramental eating of the body of Christ, also thrust oral eating of the same upon the Church, and teach that the true and natural body of Christ, existing corporeally in, with, and under the bread or the species of bread, is perceived and eaten by the mouth of the body no less than bread. They teach the same concerning the drinking of blood. We prove this opinion of the Lutherans and Papists to be false by the following arguments: I. Christ is no longer in His body in, with, and under the bread of the Lord’s Supper. Therefore He is not eaten corporeally and orally in, with, and under the bread. The antecedent was proved above. II. The oral eating of the body of Christ was not instituted by Christ. Therefore it is not to be commended or thrust upon the Church. The antecedent is proved: I. Because it is impious and horrible, such as anthrōpophagia [Greek: cannibalism] has always been held. Whence Augustine, l.3 De doctr. Christ. c.16, says: “The expression of Christ, ‘Unless you eat the flesh of the Son of man and drink His blood,’ etc., when it seemed to command a crime or wickedness, is figurative, which commands to be a partaker of the passion of the Lord, and sweetly and usefully to store up in memory that His flesh was crucified and wounded for us.” II. Because it is impossible. For neither can the lacerated flesh of Christ suffice for all, much less can the whole be received and eaten orally by all communicating simultaneously at the same time; His finitude does not allow this, which in eternity He never lays down nor will be able to lay down. Whence Christ strikes down the dream of oral eating with the argument taken from ascension into heaven, John 6:36. III. Because it is useless. For the flesh of Christ (namely eaten orally and in a Capernaitic manner) profits nothing, John 6:36. Here indeed the adversaries cry out and say it is more than Turkish blasphemy to say: The flesh of Christ profits nothing; and therefore they prove with many things that the flesh of Christ profits very much, because it is antilytron [Greek: ransom] for our sins. II. Because it is delivered for us for the remission of sins. III. Because it is given for the life of the world. IV. Because it was not assumed in vain by the Logos [Greek: Word], etc. All of which we freely profess to be most true and believe with the heart; but we say they make nothing at all to the present matter. For this is not asked: Whether the flesh of Christ profits? but, Whether its oral eating, or insofar as it is eaten orally and in a Capernaitic manner, profits? The former we affirm in every way, so the latter we deny in every way, and we desire it to be proved by the adversaries. For us it is most easy to prove the contrary from their own hypothesis. For if the flesh of Christ, insofar as it is eaten orally, profited, it would also profit the impious and unbelievers, because it is said to be eaten orally by them also. But it profits them nothing. Thus far our second argument. III. Against the Papists this reason militates strongly: the eating of the flesh of Christ instituted in John 6 is necessary for salvation. But oral eating is not necessary for salvation. Therefore the oral eating of the flesh of Christ was not instituted in John 6, as the Papists wish, from whom the Lutherans differ in this part. The proposition is clear from v.53: “Unless you eat the flesh of the Son of man, you will not have life in you.” The assumption is proved by the example of the Fathers and faithful of the Old Testament and also of infants of both testaments. IV. If the body of Christ were eaten properly, orally, and corporeally, certainly it would be broken by teeth and conveyed into the stomach; for thus is solid food properly said to be eaten orally. But the consequent is false; therefore also the antecedent. The assumption is proved because this breaking and conveyance into the stomach would be far more cruel than the crucifixion was. Here the Papists are ingenuous, and our connected ones acknowledge the consequence as necessary; for although they judge mastication and breaking which is done by teeth to be too cruel, nevertheless they do not exempt the body of Christ eaten orally from the rest which concur with oral eating. Therefore they confess that it is swallowed, transmitted into the stomach, even into the belly of a mouse, indeed also into an unclean place—which opinion of certain Catholics recited by Bonaventure, Cardinal Turrecremata judges to be true. The Lutherans indeed abhor from this impiety, and rightly indeed; but they will never be able to maintain oral and properly so-called corporeal eating of the body of Christ truly and properly so called, unless they also admit mastication, and swallowing, and conveyance into the stomach; for without these there is no oral eating of solid food, true and properly so called, nor will there be. V. If the body of Christ had been corporeally in and with and under the bread in the first institution, and had been eaten orally and properly with it, certainly Christ Himself would have eaten His body orally when He ate the bread. But the consequent is false. Therefore also the antecedent. VI. The oral eating of the body of Christ is Capernaitic. Therefore it has no place in the Lord’s Supper. I prove the antecedent: because the Capernaitcs, when they heard that the body of Christ was to be eaten, understood it concerning corporeal and oral eating, as is evident from John 6:25. The reason of the consequent is that Christ Himself rejects and condemns this Capernaitic opinion, John 6:63. The adversaries indeed deny that their oral eating is Capernaitic, but in vain. The Capernaitic eating is none other than oral; the adversaries defend this, although they wish to seem to treat the flesh of Christ more humanely than perhaps the Capernaitcs thought it ought to be treated—although Luther does not even dissent here, nor indeed can anyone dissent who asserts and defends properly so-called oral eating. VII. If the disciples in the first institution had eaten the body of the Lord corporeally and orally, and in the same manner had drunk the blood, Christ would have died twice in the state of His humiliation: once in the administration of the Supper, and again in the crucifixion. But the consequent is most false. Therefore also the antecedent. The reason of the connection is that it cannot naturally happen that a body ceases to be alive from which blood is separated, which is crushed by teeth, and which is conveyed into the stomach—all of which happened to the body of Christ in the first administration of the Supper, if separately and properly and orally it was eaten, and in the same manner the blood was drunk. VIII. The union of our bodies with Christ is not corporeal but spiritual. Therefore also the eating of the body of Christ is not corporeal and oral. The reason of the consequent is that union arises from eating. IX. The body of Christ, now glorious, no longer suffers. Therefore it is no longer eaten properly, corporeally, and orally, nor is His blood poured out and drunk. The reason of the consequent is that a truly human body cannot be eaten properly, corporeally, and orally (in whatever manner it is said to be eaten properly, corporeally, and orally) without notable suffering; but what is not capable of suffering cannot be eaten properly, orally, and corporeally. X. If the glorious body of Christ, together with the blood, were corporeally in, with, and under the sacramental symbols, and in, with, and under them were eaten properly, orally, and corporeally promiscuously by all communicants, it would follow that it is often swallowed also by the impious and victims of hell, and buried within their bowels, and the same is the temple of Christ and of Belial. But the consequent is most false. Therefore also the antecedent. XI. If Christ had instituted the Supper for the sake of oral eating, He would have instituted it in vain. But the consequent is false. Therefore also the antecedent. The reason of the connection is that oral eating necessarily supposes corporeal presence and ubiquity of the body of Christ, which the Lutherans deduce from personal union; whence we argue in this manner: What is eaten orally several times daily under all bread and food, and cannot not be eaten, it was not necessary to command to be eaten corporeally only a few times in the year under bread alone. But from the Lutheran hypothesis, the body of Christ is eaten orally several times daily under all bread and food. Therefore. I prove the assumption: Because it is everywhere. Therefore it is corporeally under and in all bread and food, and accordingly cannot not enter the mouth with all food; for if it were separated from any food, it would not be everywhere. Indeed, it is also permitted to argue in this way: What is in the mouth before the Eucharistic bread is received, and cannot not be and remain, it is not necessary to transfer into the mouth through bread; indeed, it cannot be transferred. But from the hypothesis of ubiquity, the body of Christ is in the mouth before the Eucharistic bread is received, and cannot not be and remain. Therefore.

I. The Subject of the Thing Signified: Unbelievers Receive Only the Sign, Not the True Body

XXVII. Wherefore also unbelievers do not receive the true body of Christ in the Supper.

WEND. The arguments are: I. Because they lack the organ of receiving the flesh and blood of Christ, namely true faith. II. Because they have no true and internal communion with Christ, nor are they His members, nor are they in Him. III. Because they are dead according to spiritual life; how therefore can they be partakers of food conferring spiritual life? IV. Because they eat judgment to themselves; but not judgment but absolution from judgment does he eat who truly eats the very flesh of Christ given for the life of the world. Whence Paul says judgment is eaten and drunk not in the flesh and blood of Christ, but in the bread and wine. V. Because nothing more unworthy or more atrocious can be thought and said concerning the most glorious body of Christ than if it is drawn in and polluted by the impure mouth of the slaves of Satan.

J. An Integral Part of the Rite: The Necessity and Significance of the Breaking of Bread

XXVIII. Moreover, the breaking of bread in the Sacred Supper is necessary.

ALTING. But above all, breaking ought not to be confused with distribution, inasmuch as they are both distinguished from each other among the Evangelists, and they are distinct in the very deed of Christ, first breaking the whole bread into smaller fragments, afterward distributing it to the disciples. Then also the breaking of the bread itself ought not to be omitted. For it is an altogether necessary and essential rite, not only because it rests on the examples of Christ, Matt. 26:26, and the Apostles, Acts 2:42 and 20:7, 1 Cor. 10:16, but also because it pertains to the matter and form of the Supper. To the matter, because it completes it as a part, Matt. 26:26; to the form, because it represents to us the crucifixion of Christ, 1 Cor. 11:24.

MACC. Moreover, we so establish the breaking of bread as necessary in the Lord’s Supper that without it the sacrament indeed consists, but not the integrity of the sacrament. For it is not an essential part of the Lord’s Supper, such as are the symbols with the rite and the promise of grace annexed to the rite, but it is a part integrating the rite, such as are the blessing of the bread, breaking, distribution, reception, eating; also the blessing of the cup, taking, drinking.

WAL. Concerning the breaking of bread there is some controversy among the Reformed themselves, namely whether it pertains only to distribution or also to representation, whether it is an indifferent thing or absolutely necessary. I see some of us vary somewhat here. Beza, Zanchius, Aretius, and some others seem to understand this chiefly concerning distribution, because in the other part of the sacrament there is nothing which corresponds to it—for Christ does not seem Himself to have poured the wine into the cup, but to have received it poured by others and distributed it; and because the Hebrew phrase is to break bread to someone, as Isa. 58:7, for to distribute. Whence some judge that this breaking can be done before the action, that the bread may then be distributed more conveniently in a great multitude of men; therefore the thing is in some way adiaphoron [Greek: indifferent]. Whence also in the Church of Basel and certain other Reformed Churches for a long time breaking was not used—whether it is now, I do not know. Nevertheless, most think otherwise and wish it to be part of the sacramental rite. I. Because all the Evangelists made mention of it, and the Apostle expressly says, 1 Cor. 10:16: “The bread which we break.” II. Because in the thing signified this word is also used with relation to the sign, as 1 Cor. 11:14: “This is the body which is broken for you”; likewise, “This is the blood of the New Testament which is poured out for the remission of sins,” ekchynomenou [Greek: being poured out], Luke 22:20. III. Because the analogy of the sacrifice of Christ requires it: for both His body and soul were as it were shaken and broken with sorrows, and the pouring denotes the pouring out of blood for us. Nor can distribution alone be understood, because it is said, “He broke and gave”; and the ancients preserved it, whence it is still sung by them: “Let there be no division of the thing, let there be only a breaking of the sign,” etc., because neither the body nor the figure of the thing signified is diminished. I. But it is objected against this that in the use of the cup this pouring cannot conveniently be shown. For it is not said that Christ poured wine into the cup or poured it out, nor can the very drinking have the place of pouring, because it is taking, not offering, unless we say the very pouring of wine into the mouth of the one drinking. I prefer, however, the pouring into the cup from which one drinks. II. Because Paul does not say “the cup which we pour out,” although he said concerning the bread “the bread which we break,” but “the cup over which we bless”; although if there were here a representation of the sacrifice of Christ, it seems the former ought to have been said. Yet this does not seem necessary, because the analogy of the one demonstrates the use of the other. III. Because breaking is placed before giving, for it is said, “He broke and gave.” But in the sacrifice Christ gave Himself that He might be broken, for He delivered Himself into death. This is true indeed, but He also delivered Himself after sorrows and bruisings into death and into the food of our faith. Therefore they prefer to say that the breaking was a preparatory action for the Supper, not a part of the Supper, just as the pouring of wine from a larger cup into the chalice, which accordingly can admit variation and therefore is not absolutely necessary. Although we indeed do not dare to say on account of these reasons that it is absolutely necessary for the being of this sacrament, nevertheless we judge it pertains to the well-being, because all the Evangelists made mention of that breaking, and it is safest to follow Christ’s example even in the smallest things where it can be done.

K. The Minister of the Supper: The Same as the Minister of the Word, Lawfully Called

XXIX. The minister of the sacrament is the same as that of the Word, constituted by the Church for this office.

WAL. I. Because the administration of all sacraments pertains to pastors legitimately called. II. Because it is theirs to seal the word solemnly through the sacraments, whose it is to announce the word as ambassadors of God; whence pastors are also called ambassadors of God and dispensers of the mysteries of God, 1 Cor. 4:1 and 2 Cor. 5:20. III. Because Christ went before here by His own example, who Himself administered this sacrament among His disciples as Pastor of His Church. IV. Because no contrary example can be brought from Scripture nor from the whole primitive Church. But whatever is not from faith is sin.

The question is asked: Whether elders or deacons can offer the cup, as is customary in the French Churches? Resp. This is permitted: I. Because that offering is not the making or consecration of the sacrament. II. Because Christ commanded the disciples, and Paul all, that they should distribute among themselves. III. Because in the ancient Church deacons carried it to the sick. Hence also among us, one communicant is accustomed to offer to the next following.

But it is asked: Whether those pastors, that they may be able rightly to celebrate this sacrament, ought to be priests? Resp. This matter will be treated ex professo [Latin: expressly] when that question is examined: whether the Lord’s Supper is a properly so-called sacrifice? Resp. I. Now it will suffice here to say that not a single iota [Greek: jot] exists in the whole Scripture of the New Testament by which they prove the name of priest is attributed to pastors of the New Testament. All Christians indeed are called priests, but in another sense; nor are pastors called in any peculiar manner to any priestly act, except to the preaching of the word and administration of sacraments and discipline. II. Indeed, the Apostle expressly urges in Heb. 7 and 9 that the priesthood of the Old Testament is abolished and completed in Christ our Savior alone. I. For what they object concerning the passage Acts 13:2, leitourgountōn autōn [Greek: as they were ministering], as if leitourgos [Greek: minister] signified priest, is frivolous, because leitourgos is any administrator. Whence also the magistrate is called God’s leitourgos, Rom. 13:6, and the angels, Heb. 1:7. II. Then, what the Apostle says that he hierourgein [Greek: performs sacred service], Rom. 15:16. Resp. I. The word hierourgein signifies to do or administer any sacred things, and the Apostle there asserts that he hierourgein [performs sacred service with] the Gospel, not properly the sacraments, that he might offer the Gentiles to God as a holy victim. Therefore it is a manifest metaphor by which he denotes a spiritual mode of sacrificing, not such as the Papists dream.

Moreover, here it is asked whether the minister of this sacrament can administer this to himself. For there are some among the Lutherans who deny this, like Pelargus in Schola fidei, and he brings the argument: because no one can baptize himself, and because no one can conveniently be simultaneously administrator and receiver of the sacrament. Resp. The example of Christ here is manifest, who Himself communicated with His disciples. But nothing such is read concerning baptism. II. Necessity requires this in places where there is only one pastor. And III. the practice of the ancient Church. Indeed, in the Nicene Synod a canon exists by which a pastor is excommunicated who, administering sacraments to others, does not himself communicate. But concerning baptism there is another reason: Because the example of Christ here is manifest, who was baptized by John, not by Himself. II. Because those to be baptized are not yet baptized, and accordingly are not capable of any such sacramental actions under the New Testament. For just as one who is not baptized cannot be a pastor, so neither can he baptize himself who is not baptized.

L. Integrity of the Sign: Communion in Both Kinds, Bread and Wine, for All Communicants

XXX. Both parts of the sacrament are to be given to individuals: bread and wine.

GOM. Concerning the rite of wine, Sacred Scripture relates that Christ, having received the cup of wine, gave it to His disciples and commanded that they should all drink from it, Matt. 26:27, and affirms that they all drank, Mark 14:23, and this similarly was handed down by the Apostles to the Church and observed in it, it attests, 1 Cor. 10:16 and 11:25, 27. Whence rightly Pope Gelasius thus decreed: “Either let them receive the whole sacraments, or let them be kept from the whole. Because division of one and the same mystery cannot come to pass without great sacrilege,” De conse. dist. 2, can. comperimus. And Pope Soter: “He constituted that the sacraments of the body and blood of the Lord are to be received by all faithful penitents.” But on the contrary, the apostate Roman Church devotes with curses in this manner its own Council opposing this precept of Sacred Scripture and the consonant decree of the ancient Popes: “If anyone says that by God’s precept or by necessity of salvation, all and each of Christ’s faithful ought to receive both species of the most holy sacrament of the Eucharist, let him be anathema,” Concil. Trid. sess. 21, Can.1.

JUN. But who gave this authority to mortals of treating divine things at pleasure? Paul, Gal. 3:15, wishes that nothing can or ought to be added even to a ratified testament of man; much less to the testament of the Son of God, whose last will is revealed to us in the Gospel, Matt. 26:27, that we should receive, eat, and drink those things which are offered to us. Nor ought this cavil to have place, that this was commanded only to the disciples; for by the same reasoning, laymen, as they call them, would be kept from communion of the body. Moreover, it should be noted that the body of Christ is offered to us in the Supper insofar as it was dead and bloodless, offered on the cross for us, and we drink His blood not insofar as it is in the veins of the body, but as it was poured out. “This is the blood,” Christ says, Matt. 26:28, “which is poured out for many for the remission of sins.”

TRELC. There is sin in the mutilation of the elements, or communion under one species only, against the Lord’s institution, apostolic tradition, the end and dignity of the sacrament, and finally the Orthodox consent of the more ancient Church. Against Christ’s institution: For whether you look at the deed of Christ and the Apostles in the first Supper, both were given, both were received; whether at the words, the preceptive ones indeed include a command concerning both: “Take and drink”; the iesin [?] are enunciated concerning both, bread and wine: “This is my body” and “This is my blood”; the exēgētika [explanatory ones] propose the promise on both sides. Against apostolic tradition: For to the whole Corinthian Church, from the authority of the Lord, the Apostle enjoins the necessity both of eating the bread and of drinking the wine, which he proposes to be observed not for one age but for all, the consequence of the text easily proves. Against the end and dignity of the sacrament: For the end is to seal our perfect refreshment in Christ, which is rendered imperfect by the mutilation of the other sign. But the dignity is to propose that grace of the covenant in a more clear manner than it was proposed in the Old Testament to those who all equally participated of the Paschal lamb and of the water from the rock, as the history and Pauline application teaches, 1 Cor. 10:1-2. Against the Orthodox consent of the more ancient Church: For that whole ancient and purer Church felt that the communication of both species pertained not to the clergy alone but equally to the laity; it was ignorant of concomitance, which arose from the depraved custom of dipped Eucharist after one thousand two hundred twenty years, and was afterward confirmed in the Councils of Constance, Basel, and Trent.

WAL. Although by special privilege the Synod of Basel conceded to certain Bohemians that they might receive the sacrament under both species. The Papists except that by the word “all” are understood only the Apostles, who were priests, because Christ celebrated the Supper with the Apostles alone. Resp. Let this be conceded, although some think that the rest of the household also communicated with Christ, but so be it. I. I say this does not agree with their hypothesis, who say the Apostles were made priests only then when Christ afterward said, “Do this in remembrance of me.” II. Nor can the Apostles here be considered as administrators of this sacrament, but only as communicants, since Christ was the administrator of this Supper; and the Papists, if their other sacrificers obtain only the place of communicants, concede only one species to them. III. From the fourth reason posited above it is manifest that Christ here understood the whole Church in the name of the Apostles, when He said: “This is the New Testament in my blood which is poured out for you.” This cannot be understood of pastors alone. Therefore neither can that. IV. If Christ here instituted the cup only for pastors, or as they speak, for priests, then it follows that the bread also was instituted only for pastors, and accordingly the whole sacrament pertains to pastors alone, to whom alone this was instituted. Pleasant is the response of John Frederick, Elector of Saxony, in the Diet of Augsburg in the year 1530, when it was thus responded by some: “I did not know,” he said, “that the word ‘all’ signifies priests. It is also written: ‘You are clean, but not all.’ Are there also the word ‘all’ perhaps taken for priests?” Inst. But this, some among them say, is not absurd, because here He did not institute the Supper for laymen but for priests. Resp. I. If this is not absurd, then it follows that the Apostle in 1 Cor. 10 and 11 wrongly refers this to the whole Church, and that he received this from the Lord that he might hand it down to them, 1 Cor. 10:16: “The bread which we break and the cup over which we bless”; and 1 Cor. 11:23: “I handed down to you what I received from the Lord.” II. Then nowhere will the Supper have been instituted for laymen; therefore it will not pertain to them.

Obj. That in the practice of the Apostles sometimes mention is made only of bread, Acts 2:42: “They were continuing steadfastly in the doctrine of the Apostles and in communion, in the breaking of bread and in prayers.” Thus Acts 20:11 it is said that Paul broke bread with the disciples. Resp. I. Many deny that here it treats of the Lord’s Supper, but of the taking of common food, to testify concord and mutual charity, which seems to be proved from Acts 2:46: “Continuing daily with one accord in the temple, and breaking bread from house to house, they took food in exultation and simplicity of heart.” Inst. But in this way daily feasting would be indicated, which would not be of great praise to the Apostles and that primitive Church. Resp. I. This is denied, but concord is indicated, not that they feasted all day; for the things which are added sufficiently refute this; but that, content with simple food, they conversed mutually among themselves. II. Let it be granted that it treats of the Lord’s Supper, as both Luther and Calvin concede; we say there is manifest synecdoche, because otherwise the Apostles would have consecrated only bread, which they themselves do not concede; and it is expressly said, Acts 20:11, that the Apostle broke bread with the disciples. III. It would follow that the Supper was also celebrated with the cup alone, because the Apostle in 1 Cor. 12:13 makes mention only of the cup, when he says: “We were all made to drink into one Spirit.”

M. The Manner of Receiving: The Sacred Symbols to Be Given into the Hands, Not Thrust into the Mouth

XXXI. It is fitting that the sacred symbols be given into the hands of individuals, not thrust into the mouth.

WAL. The question is asked: whether the signs ought to be thrust into the mouth by the administrator, or taken by the hands of the participants? Resp. Although if it is done without superstition, either can be tolerated, nevertheless it is certain that reception which is done by hands corresponds to the action of Christ, since the hands of believers are no less holy than the mouth, and both reception is attributed to faith in Scripture; for faith is compared both to the hand and to the mouth, John 1 and 6, Phil. 3, etc.

N. Use, Reservation, and Adoration: The Supper as a Holy Action, Not to Be Reserved or Worshiped

XXXII. Outside use, the bread of the sacrament neither ought to be preserved nor carried about; it should never be adored.

WAL. We deny that this blessed bread and wine ought to be reserved or carried about, as is customarily done among the Papists. I acknowledge indeed that in the ancient Church portions of blessed bread and wine were carried to the sick, but at that time when communion was celebrated, so that thus the sick might cultivate communion with the rest of the Church. Which, although it is not to be imitated rashly because we do not have a precept or example of this thing in Scripture, and because thence have arisen certain Papal superstitions, nevertheless we do not dare to condemn it as absolutely illicit, because it seems to retain the communion of saints and not to enervate the use of the sacrament, and I know it is observed in some Reformed Churches. Nevertheless, this Papal reservation or carrying about cannot be borne outside the time of communion: I. Because it conflicts with the institution of Christ, who reserved nothing of it, nor consecrated anything except that it might be distributed in His presence; for He broke and gave, with the command, “Eat, drink”; and the Apostles ate and drank from it, they reserved nothing; but Christ commanded, “Do this,” etc. II. From the apostolic practice, 1 Cor. 10:16, where the bread which we break is said to be communion. But reserved bread is not broken, and accordingly is not communion of the body of Christ; and 11:26: “As often as you eat or drink,” etc., not “when you have reserved or carried about.” III. Because many inconveniences follow from it, such as superstitions, venerations, candles, etc.; likewise corruption of the elements into worms, etc., concerning which in the cautions of the Mass; likewise hence arose the mutilation of the sacrament, since the cup cannot so conveniently be reserved or carried about. IV. The example of all other sacraments in the Old Testament. God expressly commanded that nothing be reserved from it, Ex. 12:10. Thus concerning the peace offerings to be eaten, concerning manna. Thus water in baptism is not reserved or carried, because it is not a sacrament except in action, and therefore the words of the sacrament are expressed through action, as “baptize,” “do this,” “take, eat.”

1. It is objected that it is the body of Christ before it is eaten. Therefore whether we wait a moment or some days to communicate the sick, it comes to the same thing. Resp. I. In the sense in which they wish, we deny it is the body of Christ. II. Mark relates the words so that he first relates that Christ gave to His disciples and they ate, and afterward He said: “This is my body.” II. We deny there is equal reason, because what is to be distributed that it may be eaten in the same act or during that public action, as is clear from Christ’s example, not that when the action is dissolved this should be done.

2. Obj. The consolation of the sick is pretended. Resp. I. No consolation of the sick is to be sought outside God’s word. II. Communion can be instituted among the sick, if it is judged necessary, and that through pastors in some assembly of the faithful, as is customary in the English Churches, among those who are to be punished, to be done in prison. But D. Beza seems to dissent, because this action is public, not private; nor are his arguments of small moment: I. Because the Supper is an ecclesiastical action, not of one household alone. If therefore some church is gathered in a private house, there is another reason, Matt. 18:20, Acts 20:7, 11. The Paschal lamb could not be slain except in that place where the whole Church convened, Deut. 16:6. Although in Ex. 12:4 it seems also to have been slain in private dwellings by individual fathers of families before the ceremonial law was fully promulgated, which afterward was forbidden. III. Because the Supper is called synaxis [Greek: assembly], synerchomenōn hymōn epi to auto [Greek: when you come together in one place], “when you are gathered together in one place,” 1 Cor. 11:20. But that is not of one or of one household, but of the Church. IV. Because either this cannot be furnished to all the sick in time of epidemic diseases, or polyēsia [Greek: multilocation] will have to be used, which is against the rule of James, 2:9. These arguments therefore are such that they cannot be easily refuted, and altogether prove that the sick alone outside the time of communion ought not to be communicated with. But if some little church is gathered in private dwellings and a pastor is present who celebrates the sacrament, there seems to be another reason. Because, however, this is urged with many inconveniences, it would be better to omit it completely, as is done in our Churches, especially in open Churches, because no example of this thing exists in Scripture, and accordingly it is done without faith. In Churches under the cross, the Church is wherever there is an assembly of the pious, even of two or three, Matt. 18:20. Thus far concerning the reservation and carrying about of the sacrament. Adoration follows.

We do not deny some veneration and reverence in receiving this sacrament. But we deny Papal adoration as manifestly idolatrous. I. Because Christ or the Apostles instituted nothing such in the celebration of the Supper; Christ commanded to eat, to drink, nowhere to adore. Therefore adoration, as ethelothrēskeia [Greek: will-worship], is to be condemned from Matt. 15:9. II. This adoration rests on the corporeal presence of the body of Christ in the Supper. But that has already been refuted above. III. Christ is to be adored there where we are commanded to seek Him by faith. But we are commanded to seek Him in the heavens at the right hand of the Father, Col. 3:1, Phil. 3:20, Heb. 1:3. IV. No sacrament was ever adored. Therefore neither is this. We concede indeed that Christ ought to be adored in the sacrament and in every place, but we deny that the sacrament itself is to be adored. V. All adoration by which a creature is adored together with the Creator is idolatry. But Papal adoration, by which they adore the Eucharist, is such adoration. Therefore, etc. The major is beyond controversy. The minor is thus proved: because they adore the accidents of bread with one adoration together with Christ, whom they wish to be subject here. But those accidents are no less creature than the substance of bread.

Here they except: The accidents are united with Christ, just as clothing is considered with a king in his veneration; therefore Christ clothed with those accidents is adored. Resp. That Christ is clothed with the accidents of bread is absurd and nowhere written. II. Why therefore do they not adore in man when he has participated of the sacrament? They respond: There are two substances there. Inst. Gold and the sacrament are also two substances. They respond: But on account of the dignity of man there is fear of offense and idolatry. Inst. Indeed, no less fear is in a golden or wooden pyx; for this is proper to idolatry: to wish to adore God in gold and silver, Dan. 11:38. Inst. But we adore Christ under the accidents. Resp. Thus the Gentiles could except that they adore God under fire or a statue or their idol, because God is present in all places; nor yet on that account are they less idolaters, since Scripture teaches that God is to be worshiped in spirit and truth. Then the Holy Spirit is present, from their opinion, to the water in baptism, that He may regenerate man through it; will they therefore adore the Holy Spirit in water or prostrate themselves before water? VI. All adoration which is not from faith is sin. But the Papists acknowledge that no one can know with certain faith whether the host is truly consecrated. Therefore. The minor is manifest, because many cases can occur through which it happens that there is no consecration, as if the priest himself is not rightly called or consecrated, or by a legitimate bishop; if he does not have the intention of consecrating, or of consecrating fewer hosts, or if the bread is not made from wheat, or wine without water, or water without wine, or more water than wine, and very many similar things. Inst. But then good intention suffices. Resp. Can good intention therefore make that idolatry is not idolatry? This is absurd. II. Faith and word are correlatives; where is the word here by which this is promised to good intention?

It is also asked whether the Eucharist should be received with knees bent? We read nothing in Scripture concerning genuflection; for the disciples reclined with Christ when He administered the Supper. And although they excuse themselves that they do not adore the bread but Christ in the heavens there, nevertheless because it has the appearance of Papal adoration, it is therefore better to omit it. But whether we ought to communicate standing or sitting does not seem to matter much, because the Passover was eaten first by those standing, Exod. 12:11. Nevertheless, the disciples reclined with Christ; and sitting seems to convey more the appearance of a sacred feast than standing, and the mind is more attentive to the present matter of those sitting than of those standing.

MACC. Moreover, here it is asked what bodily posture ought to be used in receiving the Lord’s Supper: whether namely we ought to do this standing, or bending the knees, or sitting? Resp. To receive the Eucharist standing around the table detracts nothing from the rites and form of institution, yet it is not the most fitting posture, because it is not the ordinary posture of guests; and for that reason it obscures that dignity to which He has raised us and the familiarity to which the Lord has called us. To bend the knees violates the precept concerning avoiding idolatry in many ways.
