To receive sitting is most fitting, because thus neither are the rites of institution violated, nor does this posture carry with it danger of superstition or idolatry; it better expresses the dignity and familiarity to which we are called, and is commended to us by the example of Christ Himself and the Apostles in the first institution, and of the apostolic Churches afterward.

O. Time and Frequency: Liberty as to Seasons, Provided the Supper Be Rightly and Often Celebrated

XXXIII. The Supper can be celebrated at any time, provided it is done holily.

WAL. It is certain that Christ instituted the Supper on that night in which He was betrayed, but the reason is added: because after the last Passover was celebrated, which ought to be slain between two evenings, He wished to institute the Supper and was very near to His passion. That this circumstance of time is not to be observed necessarily, but another convenient time can also be chosen, as has been done by the Christian Church, is clear: first, because there is no command of this circumstance. For Christ indeed says, “Do this,” He does not say, “Do this at the same time.” Then the apostolic practice shows the same thing, Acts 20:7: “On the first day of the week, when the disciples had come together to break bread, Paul discoursed to them,” etc., but because he prolonged the speech until midnight, it could seem that here also he began late. But the passage 1 Cor. 11:18 and 20, synerchomenōn hymōn epi to auto, “when you come together in one place, this is not to eat the Lord’s Supper,” because he says, “this one is hungry, that one is drunk.” But the faithful did not convene in the evening, unless perhaps in time of persecution, which was not yet here; therefore they also celebrated at that time. II. The time of reception also is not defined, namely how often one ought to communicate. One ought not to communicate only once, as is clear from 1 Cor. 11:26: “As often,” etc.; likewise, synerchomenōn autōn [Greek: as they come together], etc. Then by the example of the Passover. Third, because we are regenerated once, we are to be fed often, etc. Therefore this also is left to the liberty of the Church. In the beginning they seem to have communicated on individual days, from Acts 2, as Augustine relates, De Ecclefiæ dogmat. c.53: “I neither praise nor reprove the daily reception of Eucharistic communion; however, I urge and exhort that all communicate on all the Lord’s days.” Afterward on individual weeks. Fabianus prescribed that they should communicate three times annually, namely at the three major feasts; but finally once a year, around Easter.

The question is asked: Whether those feasts ought to be chosen? Resp. If it is done without superstition, we concede they can be chosen on account of the greater frequency of men, and because then the benefits of Christ are recalled to memory; but nevertheless it would be better that this not be observed so scrupulously, because we seem to ascribe some greater sanctity to days than to other preaching days, and especially to the Lord’s day, which is a remnant from the Papacy. But the time of duration is until He comes, namely to judgment.

P. Rejection of the Mass: No True Propitiatory Sacrifice for the Living and the Dead

XXXIV. But there is here no Mass or sacrifice truly and properly expiatory offered by priests for the sins of the living and the dead.

JUN. The Mass is said from missio [Latin: sending], Isid. Etymol., Honor. l. De Euch., as formerly those prayers and supplications by which sermons were concluded (today “collects” among the Papists), as the offerings sent by the faithful, were called missæ [Latin: Masses], as Cyprian, Ep. 14 and lib. de bono patientiæ, said remissa peccatorum [Latin: remission of sins] for remission; and that from this old formula accustomed to be pronounced by the deacon before the sermon: “Catechumens and whoever does not communicate, go outside”; and the other: “Go with peace, the Mass is ended.” Which rite in the progress of time was afterward repeated before the dismissal of the sermon. Hence it is that the people were accustomed to call their liturgy nothing other than Mass, after in individual Eucharists they heard that formula twice, as Poly. Virg. testifies, l.3 c.11, which, like most other things, the more ancient Church derived from the institutes and customs of the ancients, whose sacred things were accustomed to be dismissed with a similar conclusion, just as when the sacred rites of Isis were completed, the grammateus [Greek: scribe], announcing the going home to the people, said, laois apheis [Greek: the people are dismissed], “Go, the Mass is ended,” namely for the people. For in the beginning of the nascent Church (with Durandus himself confessing, Ration. divin. offic. lib.4 c.1), the Mass was accustomed to be said otherwise than now; and as the Papist Hist. Walaf. Strab. testifies, De reb. Ecclef. c.2, in these words: “What we now do with manifold office of readings, chants, and consecrations, all that Christ, the Apostles, and after them the nearest ones performed simply by prayer and commemoration of the Lord’s passion, as He Himself commanded. And it is from the relation of elders that in the first times Masses were accustomed to be done thus, with only the Lord’s Prayer premised.” They define their Mass as a truly propitiatory sacrifice by which Christ is immolated to God by a priest for the sins of the living and the dead, Concil. Trid. sess. 22 c.2, Bellarm. l.1.6.5 De miff. We on the contrary call it a diabolical abuse of the sacred Lord’s Supper and eidōlomania [Greek: idol-madness]. Let us see in order how falsely they, how truly we. First, the Mass overturns the eternal priesthood of Christ; for it does not admit a successor, since Christ is immortal, inasmuch as He Himself was made and named by His Father a high priest forever, according to the order, that is, according to the similitude of Melchizedek, unique, whose typical priesthood He fulfilled, Heb. 5:5, 10 and 7:7. The adversaries assert that the bread and wine offered by Melchizedek to Abraham was a type of the future Mass. Resp. Moses recites those little gifts as tokens of Melchizedek’s humanity toward Abraham wearied from the way, with no mention made of sacrifice. Here they urge that in the text it is said he was priest of the Most High. Resp. D. Paul refers that to the blessing which Abraham received from the priest, as from one greater than himself, Heb. 7:6-7. Nor does the authority of the Fathers patronize them anything. Let it be granted that they call the Supper a sacrifice. But what sort? A memorial of that unique sacrifice of Christ performed on the cross, Augustine, l.20 Contra Faust. cap.18; a thanksgiving and commemoration, lib. de fide adv. Petr. Diacon.; an image and testimony, lib contra adverf. legis & Proph.; every good work pleasing to God, De civit. Dei l.10 c.6; earnest and pious prayers, Tertull. Ad Scapul. Hence the Supper is called Eucharist by Irenaeus, l.4 c.32, 34. Thus the Eucharistic sacrifice is well called, as David calls his prayer incense, Ps. 141:2; thanksgivings sacrifices of praise, Ps. 51:21; the same calves of the lips, Hos. 14:2. By this reasoning all the faithful ought to be priests, Apoc. 1:6. Thus good works in the New Testament are everywhere called sacrifices, Rom. 15:16, Phil. 2:17, Apoc. 5:8, Heb. 5:15, Rom. 12:1. Thus the faithful themselves are called a holy sacrifice, to offer to God spiritual hosts, 1 Pet. 2:4. The Sacred Supper is of such a kind, not hilastikē [Greek: propitiatory], which in the New Testament is only one, that of Jesus Christ, once performed on the cross, Heb. 6:24. Second, as the priesthood, so the Mass overturns the cross and passion of Christ, while it erects an altar in the greater and lesser canon. But if this High Priest once manifested Himself through the immolation of Himself, Heb. 9:26; if by His one oblation we are perfected forever, Heb. 9:4 and 10:10, so that where there is remission of sins (but there is that of all the faithful), there is no longer oblation for sin, Heb. 10:18; where after receiving knowledge of the truth there is sin, there no host remains for sins, Heb. 10:26—how impiously is it repeated at the altar of the Mass? For either the sacrifice of Christ once performed for us on the cross lacked the power of eternal purification, or if it was present, the one suffices for all ages; but we apply it to ourselves by faith, not by the Mass, Gal. 2:16, 20 and the whole of chapter 3. Third, while the Mass promises new remission of sins, a new mode both of obtaining grace and righteousness, it buries the death of Christ, struck out from the memory of men. Moreover, if the host offered ought to be slain and immolated that you may sacrifice, as many Masses as are recited everywhere, so many times in so many places Christ must necessarily die. But what is to attenuate the unique death of Christ if this is not? But if one suffices, to what purpose is that repetition in the Mass? But, they say, the Mass is an unbloody sacrifice; therefore in it the death of Christ is not repeated, which is only bloody. But this is too futile. For how dare they call Masses satisfactory if they are anaimakta [Greek: bloodless] sacrifices? For while the Apostle denies that remission happens without shedding of blood, Heb. 9:22, they must necessarily confess that the Mass is either not a propitiatory sacrifice, or if it is, it is unbloody. Fourth, it is a mere profanation of the Holy Supper. For what is the Mass? It itself daily offers to God for sins. What is the Holy Supper? It requires from God the fruit and application of the unique oblation of Christ. Thus the latter seeks what the former gives; the latter exhibits its own office; the former requires the grace of Christ through the Spirit. The Supper acknowledges God as benevolent and gracious Father; the Mass makes Him its debtor. In the former Christ is offered to us by God; in the latter Christ is offered to God by the sacrificers. The Mass wishes to repeat daily that sacrifice of which, once offered and no longer to be offered, the Holy Supper is a mnēmosynon [Greek: memorial]. Finally, with transubstantiation posited, the Mass snatches Christ from heaven, where He sits at the right hand of God and is about to remain until the last judgment, according to the articles of faith. To these things they affirm that their Mass profits even those not receiving it, against the Holy Scriptures. The Apostle says, 1 Cor. 11:29, those eating unworthily eat condemnation to themselves, not to others; consequently, those eating worthily eat grace to themselves alone. What therefore is their fruit to the dead, since they are received either into the bosom of Abraham immediately from death, Luke 16:22, and accordingly do not need the Mass, or to eternal torments, and accordingly cannot be helped by the Mass—what use is there of the Mass for the deceased, except to empty the purses of the credulous populace? Fifth, the Mass is truly sacrilege, thrusting a half Supper upon the Church, while it snatches the drink from the laity, with those things opposing: I. The institution of Christ, since He commanded all to eat and drink from it, Matt. 26:27. II. By reason, since the drink of the blood of Christ poured out for them is in the testament to any no less than the bread of the body dead for them; therefore to whom the thing of the sign belongs, why should the sign be taken away? III. Finally by antiquity. Chrysostom says one bread and one cup are set forth to all, and these things are as common to the layman as to the priest, Hom. 18 In 1 ad. Cor.; likewise, that the daily sacrifice is done in vain if there is no one who communicates; he who is not worthy of communion of the host is not even worthy of the prayers of the Church, Hom. 51, 61 Ad populum. When Charles the Great saw this abuse creeping in during previous centuries, he forbade it by strictest law, as if it had been interdicted by the Apostolic Canons, the Nicene and many Councils, l.1 Constit. c.6, 66 and 132. Thus Clement of Rome wishes as many holocausts to be offered at the altar as suffice for communion of the whole people, Epist. 2. Hence it is that in the Roman order (according to which formerly the solemnities of Masses were recited) the Archdeacon is said to place upon the altar as many oblations of bread and wine as can satisfy the universal people. Whence Rabanus, l.2 c.31: “When,” he says, “the office of Mass is performed, at that hour each of the faithful receives the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ.” The Muscovites still preserve this, and most Orientals, and also in the kingdom of Prester John, with one cake formed from the oblations which suffices for the whole assembly, to which an equal amount of wine is added, Sigis. lib. descript. Moscov. and Fr. Alvares in descr. Æthiopiæ. More wonderful is that among them this sacred rite is performed only in the vernacular tongue, among these the cake which I mentioned is accustomed to be consecrated only in the common and paternal language, preserving the example of Christ, the Apostles, and the more ancient Church, which the Papists impiously neglect. Sixth, I pass over the histrionic gesticulations in the Mass and that tragic action by which now with downcast, now with raised countenance, with that gait, that habit, those colloquies, not the memory but the mockery of the most mournful Lord’s passion is exercised, so that that whole Mass apparatus is more similar to a sacred, that is, abominable scene than to the Holy Supper. To make an end, where in the Mass is that breaking of bread which in the Supper Christ, and from Him the Apostle Paul, calls a symbol of communion, 1 Cor. 10:16? Wherefore up to previous centuries that custom obtained, concerning which the Roman Order thus has: “The Pontiff, coming to the altar, divides the oblations for breaking, and all the people communicate in their order.” Bede noted the use of this, saying: “Christ breaks the bread which He offers to His disciples, to show that the breaking of His body would not be without His own will and procurement and their use.” These things he says In Marc. c.14. All that has dried up in the Mass, after those little coin-like cakes, marked with the image of a cross, were ordained to be swallowed unwashed by the fasting—from which time the Holy Supper has been converted into mere idolatry by the adoration either of this cake enclosed in a box, or of Christ in it, where He is not, when we hear the Apostle speaking, Col. 3: “Seek the things which are above, where Christ is, sitting at the right hand of God”; and the ancient Church: “Lift up your hearts; we have them unto the Lord.”

PROF. And the first abuse of the Mass is that the sacrificer about to administer it uses this preamble: “I will go in to the altar of God.” For the faithful no longer have an altar under the New such as they formerly had under the Old Testament, but their altar now is in the heavens, namely Jesus Christ, as Thomas Aquinas not badly observed on v.10 of Heb. 13, where the Apostle asserts that we have such an altar from which those who serve the tabernacle today have no authority to eat, and they reduce the shadowy hosts of the Jews, abrogated by the advent of Christ, into His Church. The second abuse is in the public confession of his sins, which he directs not only to God but also to all the saints who have departed this life and to his brothers, saying: “I, guilty and unworthy priest, confess to Almighty God, and to the blessed virgin Mary, and to all His saints, and to you, brothers, that I, a wretched sinner, have sinned exceedingly against the law of God by thought, speech, deed, and omission, through my fault, through my fault, through my most grievous fault.” The third abuse is perceived in the idolatrous postulation of intercession of the dead saints, conceived in these words: “Therefore I beseech the most blessed mother of God, and all the saints, and you, brothers, pray for me, a sinner, to the Lord our almighty God, that He Himself may have mercy on me.” The fourth abuse is in this absolutory prayer to others confessing their sins: “Amen, brothers and sisters, through the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, through the help and sign of the holy cross, through the intercession of the blessed and glorious ever-virgin Mary, and through the merits of the blessed Apostles and saints, may Almighty God have mercy on you.” The fifth abuse is committed in the commemoration of merits which are ascribed to the saints by the sacrificer, who could not have entered heaven at all without the merit of Christ, and of relics for the most part fictitious, as if God would be bent to remit sins to him at the sight of them, when he says: “We pray You, Lord, through the merits of the saints whose relics are here, and of all the saints, that You would deign to pardon all my sins.” The sixth abuse is that the sacrificer calls the bread, which in the Supper is a sacrament of the host of Christ, the very host of Christ, and signifies that that earthly element profits for his and others’ salvation, both of the dead and of the living, by this supplication: “Receive, Holy Father, almighty eternal God, this immaculate host, which I, Your unworthy servant, offer to You, my living and true God, for my innumerable sins and offenses and negligences, and for all standing around; but also for all faithful Christians, living and dead, that it may profit me and them unto eternal salvation, Amen.” The seventh abuse is in the mixture of water with wine, which rests neither on Christ’s command nor on His example. For He administered to His disciples the wine or fruit of the vine without water, and commanded it to be distributed to others in imitation of Him; and therefore by the decree of the Council of Orleans 4, Can.4, that mixture was condemned, which the sacrificer venerates as mystical, saying: “O God, who wonderfully created the dignity of human substance and more wonderfully reformed it, grant to us through the mystery of this wine and water to be partakers of His divinity who deigned to become a partaker of our humanity, Jesus Christ Your Son our Lord.” The eighth abuse is in the superstitious oblation of the cup filled with wine. For before the wine, to speak in the words of the Romans, is transubstantiated or converted into the blood of Christ, the sacrificer attributes to this earthly and corruptible drink the power of conferring salvation and the odor of sweetness accepted to God, of which the former good Simeon in his canticle, Luke 2:29, and Peter, Acts 4:12, attribute to Christ alone; the latter Paul attributes to the sacrifice of Christ alone performed on the cross, Eph. 1:2. Thus the sacrificer addresses God: “We offer to You, Lord, the cup of salvation, beseeching Your clemency that in the sight of Your divine majesty, for our and the whole world’s salvation, it may ascend with the odor of sweetness, Amen.” The ninth abuse is in kakozēlia [Greek: bad zeal], or depraved imitation, both of the Jews formerly placating God with incense until the time of correction, in which God wished an end to be imposed on this figure and shadow, no differently than on the rest representing the body which we have in Christ, as the Apostle testifies, Heb. 9; and of the Magi, by their prayer customarily directed to inanimate things, which they most frequently abuse for fascination, as is clear from these words of the sacrificer thus addressing his incense: “May You be blessed by Him in whose honor You will be burned, in the name of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.” To which words he subjects these to God: “We beseech You, almighty eternal God, may Your immense majesty’ right hand deign to bless and sanctify this creature of incense, that in the power of Your holy name it may marvelously be able to drive away all incursions of unclean spirits, to expel all diseases, with health restored, wherever its smoke has blown, and to give off to You, almighty God, with most fragrant odor, perpetual sweetness. Likewise, may that incense blessed by You ascend to You, Lord, and may Your mercy descend upon me.” The tenth abuse is that the sacrificer confounds disparate species. For first, he takes bread and wine before conversion into the body and blood of Christ, and accordingly only external signs of the body and blood of Christ, for the oblation of Christ itself. Second, he calls the Mass oblation a memorial of the oblation of Christ. Third, he mixes the memorial of the passion of Christ with the memorial of the incarnation, nativity, circumcision, resurrection, and ascension of Jesus Christ, against the very command of Christ, who, as the Apostle admonishes, 1 Cor. 11:26, instituted His Supper only for this end: that in it we should announce His death and set Him forth crucified before the eyes of our mind. Fourth, he has joined to the memorial of Christ the memorial of the virgin Mary and of others who offered no expiatory sacrifice of the cross to God for us. For the fidelity of which thing we will recite the very words of the sacrificer: “Receive,” he says, “Holy Trinity, this oblation which we offer to You in memory of the incarnation, nativity, circumcision, passion, resurrection, and ascension of our Lord Jesus Christ, and in honor of the blessed Mary, ever virgin, and of all the saints who have pleased You from the origin of the world, that it may profit them for honor, but for us for salvation of soul and body.” The eleventh abuse is in the description of the thing offered, which the sacrificer calls in the plural unblemished sacrifices, saying: “Therefore, most clement Father, we humbly ask and beseech You, through Jesus Christ Your Son our Lord, that You would accept and bless these gifts, these presents, these holy unblemished sacrifices.” The twelfth abuse is in the idolatrous adoration of the lightest round host which the sacrificer elevates, in which many rites concur, neither instituted by Christ nor observed by the Apostles. The thirteenth is in the celebration of the private Mass without the communion of those standing by. For neither did Christ alone in the first institution of the Holy Supper, nor afterward did the disciples ever alone eat the sacramental bread or drink the wine, but together with others called to participation of the Holy Supper; and nothing more absurd can be done by the sacrificer than that, reciting the words of Christ distributing bread and wine equally to all the disciples dining with Him, he distributes the sacrament of the Supper to none of those standing by him; and that he omits this part of Christ’s institution, but diligently observes the other which consists in the reception and consecration of the bread and cup, as if this part were more of the essence of the Sacred Supper than that, as is falsely asserted by Bellarmine. For for this reason the Sacred Supper is called the communion of the body and blood of Christ, because all of us who are many in one His mystical body participate of that one bread, as the Apostle says, 1 Cor. 10:17. Whence the Holy Supper is sometimes called by the Greek Fathers synaxis kē koinōnia [Greek: assembly and communion], sometimes the mystery tēs synaxeōs kē koinōnias [Greek: of assembly and communion], Dion. Ecclef. Hierar. 6.3, Clem. Constit. l.8 c.10. The remaining abuses are seen in the useless preservation of bread to be eaten by the faithful in a pyx, in the ridiculous placement upon the breasts of the dead, who can neither eat nor drink nor announce the death of Christ, in the vain carrying about of the ciborium through the streets, in processions and in other ceremonies altogether dissenting from Christ’s institution.
